nfrunza (Tue, 25 Sep 2018 11:30:17 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=xMFWSLo38ept9ngat) @sakoula "it needs to be manually refreshed in order to show updates on the fabric" No, it has an interval of 1 minute, due to a performance issue

AltifBrown (Tue, 02 Oct 2018 21:38:39 GMT):

GuillaumeTong (Wed, 03 Oct 2018 02:04:10 GMT):
Has left the channel.

me_abhijeet (Wed, 03 Oct 2018 04:29:00 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=syv2HhZJqsdw2RBnP) Steps push an Image on dockerhub``` Step 1: `docker login --username=yourhubusername --email=youremail@company.com` Step 2: `docker images` Step 3: `docker tag imageid username/imagename:latest` latest or any version of your choice Step 4:~` docker push username/imagename`~ ```

me_abhijeet (Wed, 03 Oct 2018 04:29:00 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=syv2HhZJqsdw2RBnP) Steps to push an Image on dockerhub``` Step 1: `docker login --username=yourhubusername --email=youremail@company.com` Step 2: `docker images` Step 3: `docker tag imageid username/imagename:latest` latest or any version of your choice Step 4:~` docker push username/imagename`~ ```

Ferrymania (Thu, 11 Oct 2018 06:32:09 GMT):
Have anyone seen this ?https://jira.hyperledger.org/projects/BE/issues/BE-485?filter=allopenissues&orderby=priority+ASC%2C+updated+DESC I am confused about this suggestion ``` Requests from many developers to be able to run HLExplorer with fabric-ca server. 1) Use fabric-ca client and admin credentials to login to fabric-ca server. 2) Enroll HLExplorer user to fabric-ca, and store the generated user credentials in a temp directory, can be under explorer 3) Verify if user exists on the CA, if they do not, register them. 4) Verify if user exists credentials (key/cert pair) exist before enrolling, and that credentials are valid, otherwise re-enroll the HLExplorer user. 5) Minimize or avoid using CDM tools for generating credentials or enroll HLExplorer user, we want as less as possible use of command tools. Balance transfer sample has a fabric-ca server, https://github.com/hyperledger/fabric-samples/tree/master/balance-transfer#sample-rest-apis-requests , and can be used top test explorer Some suggestions how to achieve this : Suppose you launch root ca (localhost:7054) and intermediate ca (localhost:8054) on localhost. Firstly, you should register identity with hf.IntermediateCA=true attribute by root ca. For example: fabric-ca-client register --id.name ica --id.attrs '"hf.Registrar.Roles=user,peer",hf.Revoker=true,hf.IntermediateCA=true' --id.secret icapw Secondly, open intermediate ca home directory and initialize the intermediate ca: fabric-ca-server init -b icaadmin:icaadminpw -u http://ica:icapw@localhost:7054 Change port of intermediate ca (8054) and some other settings of intermediate ca in fabric-ca-server-config.yaml file. After that, you can start intermediate ca: fabric-ca-server start ```

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=tquzuTmkJZaKKjYFg) @MuhammedHafil here is config.json for basic-network in fabric-samples ``` { "network-configs": { "network-1": { "version": "1.0", "clients": { "client-1": { "tlsEnable": false, "organization": "Org1MSP", "channel": "mychannel", "credentialStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/credential", "cryptoStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/crypto" } } } }, "channels": { "mychannel": { "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": {} }, "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "6000", "eventHub": "6000", "eventReg": "6000" } } } } }, "organizations": { "Org1MSP": { "mspid": "Org1MSP", "fullpath": false, "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/home/ferrymania/fabric/fabric-samples/basic-network/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/keystore" }, "signedCert": { "path": "/home/ferrymania/fabric/fabric-samples/basic-network/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/signcerts" } }, "OrdererMSP": { "mspid": "OrdererMSP", "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/home/ferrymania/fabric/fabric-samples/basic-network/crypto-config/ordererOrganizations/example.com/users/Admin@example.com/msp/keystore" } } }, "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/home/ferrymania/fabric/fabric-samples/basic-network/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpc://localhost:7051", "eventUrl": "grpc://localhost:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com" } } }, "orderers": { "orderer.example.com": { "url": "grpc://localhost:7050" } } }, "network-2": {} }, "configtxgenToolPath": "/home/ferrymania/fabric/bin", "license": "Apache-2.0" } ``` and I add two lines in docker-compose.yml for the problem *admin peer not found* ` - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051`

push1st1k (Mon, 22 Oct 2018 09:47:42 GMT):
@Karthik1337 it seems that you have a typo in the config: `OrdererMSP.adminPrivateKey.path` has an error. It should be `/ordererOrganizations/engineering.test.com/`, not `/ordererOrganizations.test.com/`

push1st1k (Mon, 22 Oct 2018 09:51:09 GMT):
@GiovanniNapoli could you please provide your `config.json` and project structure?

"configtxgenToolPath": "fabric-path/fabric-samples/bin", "license": "Apache-2.0" }``` SOLVED: Configuration error. My secret key was pointing to the wrong file. I needed to point it to the privatekey.

jeevas (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 10:32:47 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=BrFzhY3xHhkB6Xjku) @fksaito you need to add org3 in config.json and rebuild the app. "peer0.org3.example.com": { "url": "grpcs://localhost:11051" }, "peer1.org3.example.com": { "url": "grpcs://localhost:12051" } "Org3MSP": { "mspid": "Org3MSP", "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/home/jeeva/fabric-samples/first-network/org3-artifacts/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org3.example.com/users/Admin@org3.example.com/msp/keystore" } }

jeevas (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 10:35:22 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=4MYCPyofCQZQyXubY) @anaswar which version Fabric Are you using?

jeevas (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 10:38:04 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=zB2mxdK9CTmsCCEXY) Hyperledger Composer Setup : 1. npm install -g composer-cli 2. npm install -g composer-rest-server 3. npm install -g generator-hyperledger-composer 4. npm install -g yo 5. npm install -g composer-playground 6. mkdir ~/fabric-tools && cd ~/fabric-tools 7. curl -O https://raw.githubusercontent.com/hyperledger/composer-tools/master/packages/fabric-dev-servers/fabric-dev-servers.tar.gz 8. tar -xvf fabric-dev-servers.tar.gz If based on your use case you can export Fabric version in below example Fabric 1.1 cd ~/fabric-tools export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv11 ./downloadFabric.sh Fabric 1.2 cd ~/fabric-tools export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv12 ./downloadFabric.sh Start the Hyperledger Fabric based on version Fabric 1.1 cd ~/fabric-tools export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv11 ./startFabric.sh ./createPeerAdminCard.sh Fabric 1.2 cd ~/fabric-tools export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv12 ./startFabric.sh ./createPeerAdminCard.sh Hyperledger Explorer Configuration : Before modify the config.json please check docker is up or not – use this command “docker ps” If you are using latest version (Master branch )of Blockchain Chain explorer then you should use Composer Fabric 1.2 U need to change below datas . I am giving composer datas tlsEnable - false channel – composerchannel 3. adminPrivateKey , signedCert, tlsCAcerts – path - fabric-tools/fabric-scripts/hlfv12/composer/crypto-config/../.. peers – url and eventurl Orderers – url If you are using Fabric 1.1 please follow url to configure in config.json https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/CONFIG-COMPOSER-HLEXPLORER.md

anaswar (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 11:16:16 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=zB2mxdK9CTmsCCEXY) @jeevas HLF v1.2

jeevas (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 11:30:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=8egAyR49CZTf2hGwv) @anaswar Please follow above steps. if you are using Fabric V1.2 before downloadFabric .sh and startFabric. sh, you need export Fabric v1.2 'export FABRIC_VERSION=hlfv12' . i have attached Explorer config.json . Please let me know after your configuration if you face any issues

fksaito (Tue, 23 Oct 2018 15:04:56 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=MiE3yhv9rjfsjPEpC) OK, I added Org3MSP and peer0 and peer1, needed both, from Org3 in config.json. AND changed the adminPrivateKey to fake private certs (just pointed to org1 Admin) and also changed the Org2 to fake private certs. So, probably what is needed is just the ca, not the private keys. But it needs to know in advance the topology of new Org with peers names and ports...

anaswar (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 09:29:56 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=9TW8Pdor6Eut9wahg) I was able to configure

anaswar (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 09:29:56 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=9TW8Pdor6Eut9wahg) I was able to configure Explorer using this config.json file. I added the two lines in my docker-compose.ymml file - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 after that i cleared all running containers and started fresh from scratch. Thank you @jeevas for you continuous help :)

anaswar (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 09:29:56 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=9TW8Pdor6Eut9wahg) I was able to configure Explorer using this config.json file. I added the two lines in my docker-compose.yml file - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 after that i cleared all running containers and started fresh from scratch. Thank you @jeevas for you continuous help :)

anaswar (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 09:29:56 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=9TW8Pdor6Eut9wahg) I was able to configure Explorer using this config.json file. I added the two lines in my docker-compose.yml file - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 after that i cleared all running containers and started fresh from scratch. Thank you @jeevas for your continuous help :)

nemo 8 (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 20:50:39 GMT):
```<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Explorer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Explorer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> SyntaxError: /home/ubuntu/blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json: Unexpected token n in JSON at position 4 at JSON.parse () at Object.Module._extensions..json (module.js:671:27) at Module.load (module.js:565:32) at tryModuleLoad (module.js:505:12) at Function.Module._load (module.js:497:3) at Module.require (module.js:596:17) at require (internal/module.js:11:18) at Object. LinuxLearner1 (Thu, 25 Oct 2018 23:44:35 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

adamgering (Fri, 26 Oct 2018 02:11:49 GMT):
I'm familiar with Sawtooth not Fabric, but the best way to do analytics is to either query the blockchain directly, or sync it into a database and run queries there.

adamgering (Fri, 26 Oct 2018 02:13:12 GMT):
In fact, that's true for analytics of all blockchains.

adamgering (Fri, 26 Oct 2018 02:14:50 GMT):
A minor exception for analysis of ethereum smart contracts, in as much as you only get bytecode on-chain but many people upload source code to etherscan.

RonaldReagan (Mon, 29 Oct 2018 07:31:17 GMT):
Hello good people. I have tested hyperledger explorer release-3.4, with the hyperledger fabric 1.1.0. This worked perfectly with the first-network. But when i connect the same explorer with another fabric network from sample source I found online, it fails to display on the screen. Is there anything i need to change in the client of hyperledger explorer. The fabric network is okay, and I can see that block are inserted in the database, but its not displayed on screen. (i changed my config.js , pgservices.js accordingly). I don't know what I am missing. Any ideas. Has anyone tested hyperledger explorer with any other network other than fabric sample's first-network and it worked?

AlbertCL (Mon, 29 Oct 2018 10:40:36 GMT):
anyone has connected hyperledger explorer with a custom network using docker?

nfrunza (Mon, 29 Oct 2018 11:41:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=Y8bzMweQXnm2zWFmT) @RonaldReagan You need to know the version of the fabric you try to use, verify that the network is up and running, if there is a fabric-ca that would not work with Explorer, try rerun https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/v0.3.4/README.md#Database-Setup

nfrunza (Mon, 29 Oct 2018 11:41:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=Y8bzMweQXnm2zWFmT) @RonaldReagan You need to know the version of the fabric you try to use, verify that the network is up and running, if there is a fabric-ca that would not work with Explorer, all the ports of the fabric needs to be properly specified in the config.json, try rerun https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/v0.3.4/README.md#Database-Setup

nfrunza (Mon, 29 Oct 2018 11:42:41 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=5PFQRmWA8S2kgSMkf) @tahaf10 no, we haven't tested with it.

chandrika (Fri, 02 Nov 2018 05:29:46 GMT):
Hi Experts, Would like to seek your assistance/guidance to an issue that we are currently encountering while integrating Hyperledger-explorer version 0.3.7 in Hyperledger Fabric 1.2.

chandrika (Fri, 02 Nov 2018 05:30:33 GMT):
Issue Details - In 'app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js' file there is a piece of code in the 'initializeChannelFromDiscover' method - this.client_config.peers[host] - 'this.client_config.peers' is an array (array details given below) with peer names as the keys. - But the in the above line the value of 'host' variable is coming as ip/hostname of the server where the peers are running. ============================================================================================ The array value of "this.client_config.peers" ----- { 'peer0.org1.example.com': { tlsCACerts: { path: '/home/ubuntu/.../tls/ca.crt' }, url: 'grpcs://ec2-52-15-xxx-xxx.us-east-2.compute.amazonaws.com:7051', eventUrl: 'grpcs://ec2-52-15-xxx-xxx.us-east-2.compute.amazonaws.com:7053', grpcOptions: { 'ssl-target-name-override': 'peer0.org1.example.com' } }, 'peer0.org2.example.com': { tlsCACerts: { path: '/home/ubuntu/.../tls/ca.crt' }, url: 'grpcs://ec2-18-224-xxx-xxx.us-east-2.compute.amazonaws.com:7051', eventUrl: 'grpcs://ec2-18-224-xxx-xxx.us-east-2.compute.amazonaws.com:7053', grpcOptions: { 'ssl-target-name-override': 'peer0.org2.example.com' } } } ============================================================================================ It seems there may be some issue with FabricClient.js file or some other config related file. tballast (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 08:35:01 GMT):
@titoe218 Are you sure that you're connecting to the right endpoints? Furthermore, make sure that there is a long enough delay between starting the peers and trying to connect to them. I've run into issues in the past with that.

titoe218 (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 08:44:23 GMT):
@tballast How do you configure peer url, event url? This is mine `"url": "grpcs://localhost:7051", "eventUrl": "grpcs://localhost:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com`

tballast (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 08:48:51 GMT):
Gotcha, do you have TLS properly enabled? If not, then you're going to want to change the grpcs to grpc. Furthermore, look in your docker-compose.yml file to find the endpoints. You should have something that resembles this in some way: ``` peer0.org1.example.com: container_name: peer0.org1.example.com extends: file: peer-base/peer-base.yaml service: peer-base environment: - CORE_PEER_ID=peer0.org1.example.com - CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 # - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_ORGLEADER=true - CORE_PEER_LOCALMSPID=Org1MSP volumes: - /var/run/:/host/var/run/ - ./e2e-2Orgs/${CONFIG_FOLDER}/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/:/etc/hyperledger/msp/peer:ro ports: - 7051:7051 - 7053:7053 depends_on: - orderer.example.com ``` You can see that the address is peer0.org1.example.com:7051, so your URL should be ok, as long as your ports are correct.

titoe218 (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 09:28:58 GMT):
@tballast Thanks but I try many ways as you suggested but it still not working with same error :( any ideas?

tballast (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 10:16:20 GMT):
@titoe218 Sorry, not at the moment. I will probably be trying to get this working for myself soon though, and if I run into the issue and solve it I'll be sure to let you know.

titoe218 (Thu, 08 Nov 2018 10:21:15 GMT):
@tballast Thanks so much :thumbsup:

titoe218 (Fri, 09 Nov 2018 01:28:02 GMT):
@nfrunza This is my blockchain network docker-compose file (just a part) ``` orderer.example.com: container_name: orderer.example.com image: hyperledger/fabric-orderer:1.2.0 environment: - ORDERER_GENERAL_LOGLEVEL=INFO - ORDERER_GENERAL_LISTENADDRESS=0.0.0.0 - ORDERER_GENERAL_GENESISMETHOD=file - ORDERER_GENERAL_GENESISFILE=/etc/hyperledger/configtx/orderer.genesis.block - ORDERER_GENERAL_LOCALMSPID=OrdererMSP - ORDERER_GENERAL_LOCALMSPDIR=/etc/hyperledger/crypto/orderer/msp - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_ENABLED=true - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_PRIVATEKEY=/etc/hyperledger/crypto/orderer/tls/server.key - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_CERTIFICATE=/etc/hyperledger/crypto/orderer/tls/server.crt - ORDERER_GENERAL_TLS_ROOTCAS=[/etc/hyperledger/crypto/orderer/tls/ca.crt, /etc/hyperledger/crypto/peerOrg1/tls/ca.crt] #, /etc/hyperledger/crypto/peerOrg2/tls/ca.crt] working_dir: /opt/gopath/src/github.com/hyperledger/fabric command: orderer ports: - 7050:7050 networks: mynetwork: aliases: - orderer.example.com peer0.org1.example.com: container_name: peer0.org1.example.com extends: file: peer-base.yaml service: peer-base environment: - CORE_PEER_ID=peer0.org1.example.com - CORE_PEER_LOCALMSPID=MISAMSP - CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 volumes: ports: - 7051:7051 - 7053:7053 depends_on: - orderer.example.com links: - orderer.example.com networks: mynetwork: aliases: - peer0.example.com ```

example config.json: { "network-configs": { "network-1": { "version": "1.0", "clients": { "client-1": { "tlsEnable": true, "organization": "Org1MSP", "channel": "mychannel", "credentialStore": { tkuhrt (Mon, 19 Nov 2018 17:09:35 GMT):
@feitnomore : https://jira.hyperledger.org, which requires you to login using a Linux Foundation ID, which you can obtain from https://identity.linuxfoundation.org. You can see a video on getting a Linux Foundation ID at: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=EEc4JRyaAoA

feitnomore (Mon, 19 Nov 2018 18:37:24 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=brNmt6q5xd8BcqDzH) @tkuhrt is it worth the job of creating an account to file this? Will anyone even look at it? I've re-deployed a brand new environment with 4 orgs, 2 peers per org, and my Explorer still ony see the first peer of the list...

tkuhrt (Mon, 19 Nov 2018 22:35:56 GMT):
@feitnomore : someone once said "the worst thing you can do for an open source project is to find a bug and not report it". You may be having the same problem as someone else. With a bug report, the more people that report it, the more likely it is that it will get looked at and fixed. I know it is a bit of effort, but you do have the most information on your environment and setup that will allow for the bug to be better able to be triaged and fixed.

E1120 19:17:00.546311070 24341 ssl_transport_security.cc:1227] Handshake failed with fatal error SSL_ERROR_SSL: error:14094412:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:sslv3 alert bad certificate. error: [Remote.js]: Error: Failed to connect before the deadline URL:grpcs://peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn:7051 ================================================================================================== openssl : openssl s_client -host peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn -port 7051 -CAfile /root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/ca.crt.chain 140584860137376:error:14094412:SSL routines:ssl3_read_bytes:sslv3 alert bad certificate:s3_pkt.c:1493:SSL alert number 42 140584860137376:error:140790E5:SSL routines:ssl23_write:ssl handshake failure:s23_lib.c:177: Verify return code: 0 (ok) --- openssl s_client -host peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn -port 7051 -CAfile /root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/ca.crt.chain -key /root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/server.key -cert /root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/server.crt Verify return code: 0 (ok) --- read:errno=0 ================================================================================================== Config.json: "peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/ca.crt.chain", "client": { "keyfile":"/root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/server.key", "certfile":"/root/fabric-deploy/fabric-ca-files/org1.freeexchange.cn/peer0/tls/server.crt" } }, "url": "grpcs://peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn:7051", "eventUrl": "grpcs://peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.freeexchange.cn" } }

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:37:17 GMT):
got an interesting observation regarding explorer...

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:37:38 GMT):
the dashboard screen uses the client/browser timezone to display the data

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:37:51 GMT):
and not the actual dates of the blockchain network

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:38:34 GMT):
in other words, my blockchain is running on a 2+ hour timezone, and on the dashboard, the graphs reflects transactions that happened only until the date on my desktop computers (2 hours earlier)

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:38:54 GMT):
however, if I go to transactions tab, I can see transactions that happened in the future (2 hours ahead)

feitnomore (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 11:39:02 GMT):
don't know if I could make myself clear

masterofimages (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 13:50:17 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

masterofimages (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 13:55:38 GMT):
Hi there. Has anyone been able to get explorer 3.8 working in docker with the HLF 1.3 first-network sample network? I have 3.7 working with the 1.2 sample network, but when I upgrade to 1.3/3.8 using the exact same config, explorer seems to just hang on startup, and the site won't load (connection refused). I can then revert back to 1.2/3.7 and it works with no issues. Are there any special "gotchas" required to get it working under HLF 1.3?

masterofimages (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 13:59:55 GMT):
BTW, I'm using the deploy_explorer.sh script to deploy explorer, and I'm removing all blockchain-explorer containers and images, and running ./deploy_explorer.sh --clean whenever I switch between versions to ensure that I'm starting with a clean docker setup each time.

nfrunza (Thu, 22 Nov 2018 21:43:32 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=mYehmZ3oK6QchQsYm) @masterofimages switching between fabric versions need to be verified after you do this, if you do locally you may have to update fabric samples binaries

masterofimages (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 09:09:57 GMT):
@nfrunza As far as I can tell, all binaries have been updated, as reported by byfn.sh (which verifies the version and reports 1.3.0). The network is built and verification checks run successfully, so I can´t see why explorer isn't working. I have exactly the same behaviour with another network running under HLF 1.3 (i.e. chaincode execution and node.js apps work fine, but explorer doesn't load). I then replicated the issue using the sample network to ensure it wasn't an issue with the network I was using.

nfrunza (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 13:34:25 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=ykKxEWwC8rPFBDhRD) @masterofimages after you switch fabric versions, did you run blockchain-explorer/app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/createdb.sh script

masterofimages (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 13:39:28 GMT):
@nfrunza Not directly, but I'm using the supplied deploy_explorer.sh script to build the containers, and this runs createdb.sh.

nfrunza (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 13:40:31 GMT):
you're right, --clean will rerun

masterofimages (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 15:06:48 GMT):
That´s right. I had to generate the config.json for the sample network based on the example, but that´s pretty straightforward, and it´s exactly the same as the one I'm using with explorer 3.7, which works fine.

masterofimages (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 15:13:59 GMT):
I can provide the script I´m using to build and deploy explorer if that helps, along with the config.json file. All I'm doing is running this after rebuilding the sample network with the relevant version (using bootstrap.sh) and supplying it with an explorer version (3.7 or 3.8). The script then executes the clean, checks-out the correct version, copies the config file into the correct folder, creates a symbolic link to the crypto-config, then executes the deploy.

nfrunza (Fri, 23 Nov 2018 15:38:44 GMT):

"url": "grpcs://10.0.2.15:7050" }, "orderer1.orgOrderer.com": { "url": "grpcs://10.0.2.4:7050" } } }, "network-2": {} }, "configtxgenToolPath": "/home/ubuntu/fabric-samples/bin", "license": [ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=TK8PtjBNjKZoLnDNG) @longnv1a An chance you could elaborate please? Are you able to run explorer against the first-network sample using the standard deploy_explorer.sh script supplied?

junki (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 08:59:55 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=NiFEgrNft7DsjqDy6) @nfrunza Thank you!^^

junki (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 09:03:56 GMT):
Excuse Me. I have a question!. Where does the hyperledger explorer information come from? PostgresSQL?, peer container? orderer?

longnv1a (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 09:10:55 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=pR69vysiiBkKgEebv) @masterofimages I am not using the first-network example, we create our own network.

masterofimages (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 09:28:18 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=htgfCN4M5EgmrCXgw) @junki Depends what you mean by "information". The initial configuration is done via the config.json file which you have to supply. This contains all the connectivity details required to connect to each node on the network, as well as certificate and key locations. Once explorer connects to the network and starts reading the ledger, this information is then stored in the PostgreSQL database.

masterofimages (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 09:31:22 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=irdFYHfobKRdYTrCv) @longv1a Any chance you could try to run it in a container against the first-network example? My config.json for this is as follows:

nfrunza (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 15:24:15 GMT):

acloudfan (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 18:30:45 GMT):
Anyone seen this error :thumbsup: <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Explorer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ReferenceError: host_port is not defined at FabricClient.initializeChannelFromDiscover (/home/vagrant/blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js:404:17) at Received kill signal, shutting down gracefully Closed out connections

nfrunza (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 19:19:26 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=ELZjgWnZHWGC7SkWM) @acloudfan do you run explorer in docker?

acloudfan (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 19:20:31 GMT):
@nfrunza no ... Its a native install in a VM

acloudfan (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 21:53:17 GMT):
@nfrunza solved the issue .... its a bug in the code IMHO .... it uses the host to find the peer ... since hos=localhost it is unable to find the peer ..... in my setup I have created hostnames in /etc/hosts and removed the localhost and that made it work. Also reference to host_port in FabricClient.js:404 is referring to a non existing vars

nfrunza (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 22:13:09 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=8BxXCF8MA6wmLifgq) @acloudfan Please create a jira

nfrunza (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 22:13:09 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=8BxXCF8MA6wmLifgq) @acloudfan

nfrunza (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 22:14:47 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=qYM6bR3PrdBnTTgSG) wait you can define here: /blockchain-explorer/appconfig.json

junki (Mon, 26 Nov 2018 23:55:54 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=p9H9dkyDKYBq62saQ) @masterofimages When a transaction occurs, it is stored in the database. Is it reading the database and printing it to the Web?

nfrunza (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 03:52:09 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=4veZiT67qCsQXKHgD) @junki Fabric stores transactions/blocks in internal fabric DB(levelDB, or couchDB depending how you start your fabric), Explorer queries block/transactions from fabric and stores in local postgreSQL DB that is in sync with fabric, so it would not query fabric every time you need to preview, search blocks or transactions

lys94 (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 12:02:31 GMT):
Hi:wink:. Explorer can read the transaction data from ProgresSQL. What about the key-value data? Is there any approach I can read the key-value data (like A: 90 in example02) and print it to the Explorer?

nfrunza (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 13:27:34 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=e524ba92MKgKqAZEx) @lys94 Explorer persists all queried data from fabric, and in transactions details you can see the json data in pretty format

nfrunza (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 14:51:21 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=hmrWSBa7FcjdufK58) @saikumar3349 If you scroll a little down, you can see https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md

masterofimages (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 15:04:27 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=BwKAiscJBMmctnPCS) @nfrunza Ok. Now I see the problem. There was a change made to deploy_explorer.sh on October 4th (by you) which switched the exposed port from 8080 to 8090. However, all of the documentation still refers to port 8080! I don't know why this change was made, but it should either be reverted, or the documentation updated accordingly.

masterofimages (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 15:07:44 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=KyQfHkpcSraGdMAn6) The reason was plain for me to see in the "docker ps" output when I checked the port mapping. Of course, this should have been the first thing I checked. Lesson learned!

masterofimages (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 15:09:49 GMT):
@nfrunza BTW, the client and fabric versions reported by the application are wrong for release 3.8. It still reports 0.3.7 and 1.2.

nfrunza (Tue, 27 Nov 2018 15:10:48 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=MdNAHqfrX8R2RZxbc) @masterofimages great that you found

masterofimages (Wed, 28 Nov 2018 08:07:32 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=P9TtyseiZpfsXTjpa) @yinzhiwu Depends how you are deploying. If you use the deploy_explorer.sh script to automate deployment to a container, config.json is under blockchain-explorer/examples/{your-network-name}. Follow the instructions in the "Run Hyperledger Explorer using Docker" section of https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md.

futrax (Fri, 30 Nov 2018 12:28:33 GMT):
Hi, I need some help regarding Hyperledger Explorer configured with softhsm (pkcs11). All the doc deals with a config.json file which seems to be our network and our hyperledger config. How do you configure your network if Hyperledger uses PKCS11 crypto instead "file" crypto ? For example, "Org1MSP": { "mspid": "Org1MSP", "fullpath": false, "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "fabric-path/fabric-samples/first-network/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/keystore" }, "signedCert": { "path": "fabric-path/fabric-samples/first-network/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/signcerts" } }, AdminPrivateKey is unknown since it's in my softhsm... All Hyperlerdger Explorer solution (included FabricClient) is based on configuration and file crypto, it's impossible to configure a pkcs11 crypto... Am I wrong ? Thank you foir your help.

garunkumar450 (Sun, 02 Dec 2018 06:39:15 GMT):
@zorrothefox can u please share the links of explorer branch 3.5.1 for compose setup

zorrothefox (Sun, 02 Dec 2018 06:52:27 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aP766btKwmwgTmPps) @garunkumar450 It is available in github repository itself https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer. You need to git clone the repository and then checkout the tag v0.3.5.1 (here's how to download a particular tag https://stackoverflow.com/a/792027/1336068).

zorrothefox (Sun, 02 Dec 2018 06:52:27 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aP766btKwmwgTmPps) @garunkumar450 It is available in github repository itself https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer. You need to git clone the repository and then checkout the tag v0.3.5.1 (here's how to download a particular tag https://stackoverflow.com/a/792027/1336068). Note that you don't need to create a branch, just checkout the tag as is.

yinzhiwu (Sun, 02 Dec 2018 09:53:53 GMT):

Is this expected behavior? What if i have multiple peers in channel and i want to monitor them all? ```"channels": { "mychannel": { "peers": { "peer0.example": {}, "peer1.example": {}, "peer2.example": {} }, "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "6000", "eventHub": "6000", "eventReg": "6000" } } } } }```

nfrunza (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 12:56:24 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=YG8EPwHuTBn8ZmL7Z) @ArpitKhurana1 which fabric version you're using and explorer version?

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 12:56:50 GMT):

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 12:57:04 GMT):

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 12:58:56 GMT):
if i am not wrong ''https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/utils/FabricUtils.js#L134''' shows that it only has one peer to be defaulted

nfrunza (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 13:13:35 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=jnapcEpGBHCAx4rHR) @ArpitKhurana1 you may want to read this discovery feature https://drive.google.com/file/d/19A9-iNe48MB4IZPCt0ygSY9FcOVubyZO/view?usp=sharing https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/discovery-overview.html The new event service (available since v1.1) is channel-scoped: https://fabric-sdk-node.github.io/release-1.3/tutorial-channel-events.html

nfrunza (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 13:15:02 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=7aEDYjk6T8qT8A5Jv) #### Possible cause: peer node default can't access from out of fabric network #### Possible solution: add environment CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT for peer services, For example： peer0.org1.example.com: container_name: peer0.org1.example.com image: hyperledger/fabric-peer environment: - CORE_VM_ENDPOINT=unix:///host/var/run/docker.sock - CORE_PEER_ID=peer0.org1.example.com - CORE_LOGGING_PEER=info - CORE_CHAINCODE_LOGGING_LEVEL=info - CORE_PEER_LOCALMSPID=Org1MSP - CORE_PEER_MSPCONFIGPATH=/etc/hyperledger/msp/peer/ - CORE_PEER_ADDRESS=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 - CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNALENDPOINT=peer0.org1.example.com:7051 #### Related Information: HL Explorer support for HL Fabric 1.3

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 17:49:54 GMT):
@nfrunza I already have this variable set, its related to explorer not fabric, since whichever peer i configure as first shows up as active

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 17:49:54 GMT):
@nfrunza I already have this variable set, its related to explorer not fabric, since whichever peer i configure as first, shows up as active

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 17:49:54 GMT):
@nfrunza I already have this variable set, its related to explorer not fabric, since whichever peer i configure as first, shows up as active. Do you mean that , discovery feature automatically should list all peers even if one is known?

ArpitKhurana1 (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 18:13:46 GMT):
Ok it was due to absent anchor peer

nfrunza (Fri, 14 Dec 2018 22:30:57 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=gSfX4di5Yf3FFzwpd) @ArpitKhurana1 would you be able to describe your case and we can add to troubleshooting doc., so other developers can benefit?

ArpitKhurana1 (Sat, 15 Dec 2018 04:19:27 GMT):
@nfrunza yes ofcourse, you were right about service discovery

ArpitKhurana1 (Sat, 15 Dec 2018 04:21:19 GMT):
I guess the explorer gets the peers by querying the one default peer of channel. Even if everything was working in my channel, still I had slipped setting the anchor peer as it was just single organisation

ArpitKhurana1 (Sat, 15 Dec 2018 04:22:23 GMT):
I redeployed everything again and setup anchor too, that made it work, I don't know how much anchor peer configuration helps in gossip or service discovery. But this worked

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=YhTaLXDamDN58z9iP) @qubing pm

VictoriaW (Thu, 03 Jan 2019 12:48:52 GMT):
Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed but the node-counter is correct?

VictoriaW (Thu, 03 Jan 2019 12:48:52 GMT):
Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed but the node-counter is correct?

VictoriaW (Thu, 03 Jan 2019 12:48:52 GMT):
Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed but the node-counter is correct? Edit: The reason is the container blockchain-explorer cant reach/ping the peers which are listed as down. (You can see it with the command docker exec -ti blockchain-explorer ping peer1.org1.example.com). Solution is as follows : Insert in Line 194 in deploy-explorer.sh "--add-host=peer1.org1.example.com:ipaddressO

VictoriaW (Thu, 03 Jan 2019 12:48:52 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=QRMFv9SYzEtbNTktA) Does somebody know why in hyperledger explorer peers are shown as "down" but are actual running? And why not alle peers are listed but the node-counter is correct? Edit: The reason is the container blockchain-explorer cant reach/ping the peers which are listed as down. (You can see it with the command docker exec -ti blockchain-explorer ping peer1.org1.example.com). Solution is as follows : Insert in Line 194 in deploy-explorer.sh "--add-host=peer1.org1.example.com:ipaddress" . You can do it multiple times, for each down-listed peer. This was also the solution for the non-listed peers.

jeevas (Fri, 04 Jan 2019 04:41:08 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=25JKA4DfJTConsugu) @yousaf Yes. we are fetching data from fabric database and storing data in postgreSQL. From postgresSQL we are displaying data in Hyperledger explorer.

"Create a new folder (lets call it dockerConfig) to store your hyperledger network configuration under examples (mkdir -p ./examples/dockerConfig) Save your hyperledger network configuration under examples/dockerConfig/config.json. Karthik1337 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 03:44:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=fjNWReRFpXnTsQQ9G) @KenvinNguyen Please check peer2 port. If you deployed in same system the peer2 configuration will be

Karthik1337 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 03:44:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=fjNWReRFpXnTsQQ9G) @KenvinNguyen Please check peer2 port. If you deployed in same system the peer2 configuration will be `"peer2.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "" }, "url": "grpc://org1.example.com:7051", "eventUrl": "grpc://org1.example.com:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer1.org1.example.com" } }`

Karthik1337 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 03:44:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=fjNWReRFpXnTsQQ9G) @KenvinNguyen Please check peer2 port. If you deployed in same system the peer2 configuration will be `"peer2.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "" }, "url": "grpc://org1.example.com:7051", "eventUrl": "grpc://org1.example.com:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer1.org1.example.com" } }`

Karthik1337 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 03:44:10 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=fjNWReRFpXnTsQQ9G) @KenvinNguyen Please check peer2 port. If you deployed in the same system the peer2 configuration will be ``` "peer2.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "" }, "url": "grpc://org1.example.com:7051", "eventUrl": "grpc://org1.example.com:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer1.org1.example.com" } } ``` https://github.com/Karthik-Venkatesh/Hyperledger-Multi-Organisation-Network/blob/master/explorer/dev/config.json This is my sample config.json. I hope it will help you.

doyajii1 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 04:28:16 GMT):

nekia (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 05:24:20 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=L8F4CeHKG9P5r4udJ) @CraigDrabik When you use the dockerized version, I think, you also need to change all kind of 'localhost:[port]' settings in config.json into the actual each container name ( ex. "url": "grpcs://localhost:10051" -> "grpcs://peer1.org2.example.com:7051" ). @thgoutham

Karthik1337 (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 10:44:46 GMT):

nfrunza (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 22:11:57 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=pcFdPGTxQN7NGtDgo) @nRyDevOps Explorer starts with $./start.sh , after you follow on README document, i believe you did'n build the application

nfrunza (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 22:13:30 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=Aqzyq6kSmoHmTYYqa) Did you do the steps: $mkdir -p ~/workspace $cd ~/workspace $git clone https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer.git FYI: HL Explorer Git tags: v0.3.1 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.0. v0.3.2 - to V0.3.5.1 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.1 v0.3.6 Hyperledger Explorer works with Hyperledger Fabric 1.2 $git checkout 'tag you need to use' $ cd blockchain-explorer/ Edit crypto config blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json $ cd app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/ && ./createdb.sh $ nom install $ cd client/ $ npm install && nom run build && cd .. $ ./start.sh

I would like to play around with the code and see the changes live in a dev server, instead of having to rebuild each time I change something.

nRyDevOps (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 22:39:17 GMT):
React and Angular are normally built with dev mode when in development and production during deployment. Dev mode gives on the fly updates to the React app without having to even reload the browser. More importantly without having to rebuild the app to production build.

nfrunza (Tue, 22 Jan 2019 22:40:11 GMT):

nfrunza (Thu, 24 Jan 2019 15:04:05 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=bTNox7KeEH7gKWHLv) @emiliomarin I would suggest first try fabric-samples/first-network , make sure you have the correct version of the fabric and explorer, you have a custom fabric configuration and may require a different explorer configuration. If your fabric network is configured with fabric-ca, explorer doesn't support it, we are working on adapting explorer to fabric-ca.

Peter777 (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 16:13:13 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

Peter777 (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 16:13:35 GMT):
Hello, can i restart Hyperledger explorer without delete the data in postgress db every time i restart my Fabric network? Hello, can i restart Hyperledger explorer without delete the data in postgress db every time i restart my Fabric network?

Peter777 (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 16:13:35 GMT):
Hello, can i restart Hyperledger explorer without delete the data in postgress db every time i restart my Fabric network?

nfrunza (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 17:57:12 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=kyhTAk3Jogm6kjaDB) @Peter777 It depends, if wipe out the ledger data in fabric, then you need to delete data in DB, we consider the uniqueness of the channel by the GenesisBlock, and not by the name of the channel

nfrunza (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 17:57:12 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=kyhTAk3Jogm6kjaDB) @Peter777 It depends, if you wipe out the ledger data in fabric, then you need to delete data in DB, we consider the uniqueness of the channel by the GenesisBlock, and not by the name of the channel

nfrunza (Wed, 06 Feb 2019 17:57:12 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=kyhTAk3Jogm6kjaDB) @Peter777 It depends, if you delete the ledger data in fabric, then you need to delete data in DB, we consider the uniqueness of the channel by the GenesisBlock, and not by the name of the channel

Is it possible that it will try to connect there according to a result returned by discovery? (I can see discovery being done from app.log)

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 04:22:36 GMT):

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 04:24:58 GMT):
The discovery returns a section about the orderers as such: `"orderers":{"OrdererorgMSP":{"endpoints":[{"host":"orderer0.ordererorg","port":7050},{"host":"orderer1.ordererorg","port":7050}]}}`

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 05:40:01 GMT):
@GuillaumeTong Are you woking on fabric-1.4.0 ? We had similar problem a few days before. Do you set orderers setting in your channel section ? The orderers setting seems to be **required** for network profile ([sample](https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developapps/connectionprofile.html?highlight=connection%20profile#sample) ). Please refer to [this comment](https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-542?focusedCommentId=56956&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-56956).

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 05:40:01 GMT):
@GuillaumeTong Are you using explorer with fabric-1.4.0 ? We had similar problem a few days before. Do you set orderers setting in your channel section ? The orderers setting seems to be **required** for network profile ([sample](https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/latest/developapps/connectionprofile.html?highlight=connection%20profile#sample) ). Please refer to [this comment](https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-542?focusedCommentId=56956&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-56956).

garunkumar450 (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:20:52 GMT):

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:35:32 GMT):
@nekia My current config looks like this in the channels section: ``` "channels": { "channel-name": { "peers": { "peer0.org1": {}, "peer1.org1": {}, "peer0.org2": {}, "peer1.org2": {} }, "orderers": { "orderer0": {} }, "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "6000", "eventHub": "6000", "eventReg": "6000" } } } } },``` I was already trying to add an orderers section, with the same format as peers. Looking at the sample you linked to, it seems that that format is wrong and should just be a list of strings, not empty objects. Is that correct?

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:36:18 GMT):
Something like `"orderers": {"orderer0"},`

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:41:18 GMT):
I don't think it's the same format as peers. You need to add with array format. ``` "mychannel": { "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": {} }, "orderers": [ "orderer.example.com" ], ```

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:42:31 GMT):
@nekia I confirm, my format was wrong and the one you proposed allow me to successfully launch the explorer. Thank you very much

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:43:01 GMT):
If TLS enabled, you will also need to add tlsCACerts setting for orderer.

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:43:25 GMT):
:grinning: Great!

GuillaumeTong (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:44:09 GMT):
I think It would be very helpful to update the samples on github as such for the next people who would try the new explorer.

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 06:44:57 GMT):
Yes, you are right. We are working on it.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=t3RWrmy3v2MEdYAxH) @nfrunza I could recreate this issue on my environment, too.

Kelvin_Moutet (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 07:21:36 GMT):

Kelvin_Moutet (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 07:23:26 GMT):
If you change your client to : ``` "client-1": { "tlsEnable": true, "organization": "Org1", "channel": "mychannel", "credentialStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/credential", "cryptoStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/crypto" } } } ``` Does it work ?

nekia (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 07:25:52 GMT):
Yes it works.

Kelvin_Moutet (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 07:26:16 GMT):
It surely comes from here non https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/5941ea1e516d7cb0f46bac4ef9ba9bed2769b4ec/app/platform/fabric/FabricClient.js#L149 ?

Kelvin_Moutet (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 07:27:19 GMT):
It takes the first peer on the list, whatever the client is, but we have to match/restrict the peer chosin with client org

erickrettozi (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 11:58:35 GMT):
Hello! The need to have to configure each of the Peers in the config.json file is something I would not want to have to do. For me, the ideal would be for Explorer to grab all Peers and their respective STATUS automatically, without having to add each of the Peers in the config.json. I know that for this to work, it is necessary to change the code of the Explorer to begin to recognize the Peers in the network automatically. Has anyone here had to do this? Is good idea change this logic on Explorer?

PMoura (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 13:14:33 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=432Na8CXNgyj6y7SR) Resolved. I had to define config.json pointing to paths inside the docker container and not on host machine.

ftfnunes (Fri, 15 Feb 2019 20:26:37 GMT):

nfrunza (Mon, 18 Feb 2019 17:41:02 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=PtjZXMaLn4kg3kJdb) @garunkumar450 which OS do you use? make sure you do not run as root user, try to set permissions for createdb.sh script, $chmod -R 775 createdb.sh , verify if you can access postgresql, or it is installed, or are you behind the proxy

nfrunza (Mon, 18 Feb 2019 17:42:54 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=kNLXokyG4MkciGvnW) @bh4rtp would you be able to share, 1. $docker network ls 2. $docker inspect

nfrunza (Mon, 18 Feb 2019 18:05:50 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=mfqyN2wnSrZ8QJ5zi) @ftfnunes Would you be able to share your config.json, OS you're using, node version, fabric version, can't ask maybe you can share docker compose yaml file for the fabric config

ftfnunes (Mon, 18 Feb 2019 18:29:52 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=BFsJ5DFdWDen5GjqT) @nfrunza I figured out how to configure it properly. Turns out I needed to put both the root and intermediate certificates into the .crt file referenced in the tlsCACerts in the config.json, like this: `-----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- // Intermediate CA certificate -----END CERTIFICATE----- -----BEGIN CERTIFICATE----- // Root CA certificate -----END CERTIFICATE----- `

nfrunza (Tue, 19 Feb 2019 00:05:01 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=TPgn4nrrDEBpf7jjY) @ftfnunes i'm glad it worked, i think this is a workaround

bh4rtp (Tue, 19 Feb 2019 01:02:38 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=LTZtRXkkwceE6LxnQ) @nfrunza thanks. i understood.

nekia (Tue, 19 Feb 2019 02:29:24 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=isF3ikJjgHBrtyuE4) @AlbertCL Thanks. It seems to happen when organization name("Org1") is different from mspid ("Org1MSP") at "organizations" section in config.json.

nekia (Tue, 19 Feb 2019 02:29:24 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=isF3ikJjgHBrtyuE4) @AlbertCL Thanks. It seems to happen when organization name("Org1") is different from mspid ("Org1MSP") at "organizations" section in config.json. We'll handle it in a new JIRA.

nekia (Tue, 19 Feb 2019 02:32:20 GMT):
And for the DeprecationWarning from node.js, we might need to think about doing [this kind of work](https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-942).

FlorianStoica (Wed, 27 Feb 2019 22:04:02 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=XExjEWdYiHexPEkmx) If someone is interested later on, I've modified the docker image to start monitor.sh (also some minor modifications were needed so that it finds start.sh and main.js) and this way it starts explorer after failing thus having some kind of poll, and when channel is created explorer remains started

FlorianStoica (Wed, 27 Feb 2019 22:04:02 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=XExjEWdYiHexPEkmx) If someone is interested later on, I've modified the docker file to start monitor.sh (also some minor modifications were needed so that it finds start.sh and main.js) and this way it starts explorer after failing thus having some kind of poll, and when channel is created explorer remains started

HLFPOC (Sat, 02 Mar 2019 10:04:52 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

HLFPOC (Sat, 02 Mar 2019 10:07:25 GMT):
Hi Team, I have created 2 org fabric network and configured hyperledger explorer to work on it, however, I am not able to see details of my second channel. I have mentioned channel details of both of my channels in config.josn under channels section, but in explorer screen, it shows data of only first channel. Also channel dropdown do not shows second channel name . Can anyone please help in resolving this issue ?

HLFPOC (Sat, 02 Mar 2019 10:07:25 GMT):
Hi Team, I have created 2 org fabric network and configured hyperledger explorer to work on it, however, I am not able to see details of my second channel. I have mentioned channel details of both of my channels in config.josn under channels section, but in explorer screen, it shows data of only first channel. Also channel dropdown do not shows second channel name . Can anyone please help in resolving this issue ? @nfrunza

nfrunza (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 02:31:59 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=XhGgQz56gDzwptX5a) @HLFPOC hello, if you use HLF1.2 and up, and tag v03.9.1 , please make sure to set the environment variables ```CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP``` and ```CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT``` for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.. Only default channel needs to be in config.json

HLFPOC (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 10:22:38 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=DcfvkCJ37GocKMPkr) @nfrunza Thanks for your reply, I am currently working on Fabric v1.3 and pulled latest hyperledger-explorer from github 3 days back. I checked my compose files and the env variables which you have mentioned are already configured for each peer.

HLFPOC (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 10:22:38 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=DcfvkCJ37GocKMPkr) @nfrunza Thanks for your reply, I am currently working on Fabric v1.3 and pulled latest hyperledger-explorer from github 3 days back. I checked my compose files and the env variables which you have mentioned are already configured for each peer. `CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT ` has value of the same peer (for ex, if peer address is peer0.org1.example.com, then external endpoint value is also set to same address) and `CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP` is set with value of other peer of the same organization.

habpygo (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 11:30:32 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

nfrunza (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 20:36:07 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=wwqtBNkamP3esBdaH) @HLFPOC you need to use tag v0.3.8 https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/release_notes/v0.3.8.md

nfrunza (Sun, 03 Mar 2019 20:36:07 GMT):

SashaPESIC (Tue, 05 Mar 2019 11:27:24 GMT):
starting explorer with docker-compose yields an error about not being able to find the locate command. The instalation of the command is not present in docker-compose.yaml sample, neither is possible to install it once you are inside the container.

SashaPESIC (Tue, 05 Mar 2019 11:27:24 GMT):
starting explorer with docker-compose yields an error about not being able to find the locate command. The instalation of the command is not present in docker-compose.yaml sample, neither is possible to install it once you are inside the container. Are there any ideas how to bypass this?

SashaPESIC (Tue, 05 Mar 2019 11:27:24 GMT):
starting explorer with docker-compose yields an error about not being able to find the locate command. The instalation of the command is not present in docker-compose.yaml sample, neither is possible to install it once you are inside the container. Thus, chaincode source codes are not found. Are there any ideas how to bypass this?

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=n96PciZma9Jax7y4T) @Aniket.1 My config.json is almost equal, the only difference is in the peer definition: `"peer0.org1.test_org1.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.test_org1.com/peers/peer0.org1.test_org1.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpcs://peer0.org1.test_org1.com:7051", "eventUrl": "grpcs://peer0.org1.test_org1.com:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.test_org1.com" }`

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=n96PciZma9Jax7y4T) @Aniket.1 My config.json is almost equal, the only difference is in the peer definition: `"peer0.org1.test_org1.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.test_org1.com/peers/peer0.org1.test_org1.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpcs://peer0.org1.test_org1.com:7051", "eventUrl": "grpcs://peer0.org1.test_org1.com:7053", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.test_org1.com" }` Howevere, I was not able to make it run with v0.3.9, v0.3.9.1 works for me

nfrunza (Wed, 06 Mar 2019 19:06:51 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=WsoDi4pwxhcYWdpxW) @HLFPOC try to start explorer with debug mode , and follow the logs, from root: $export HFC_LOGGING='{"debug":"console"}' && node main.js

vanitas92 (Thu, 07 Mar 2019 11:18:44 GMT):
Hello guys! Once the explorer is built, is it possible to avoid launching the application through the `node main.js` command and serve it through an http server such as nginx? Has anyone tried this approach? Thank you!

nfrunza (Thu, 07 Mar 2019 13:21:55 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=9Dd2TxCTvnCsGpHsZ) @vanitas92 very interesting concept, main.js exposes the routes, starts the connection to FLFabric and much more, maybe there is a way nginx can execute the main.js

edisinovcic (Fri, 08 Mar 2019 09:51:26 GMT):
@vanitas92 just use docker for explorer (and add it to existing network where your Fabric nodes are) -> they will communicate via http://containername:port and then you can also add nginx and expose explorer from docker network to host via nginx. Hope this isn't to complicated. :)

edisinovcic (Fri, 08 Mar 2019 09:57:43 GMT):
I don't know where to post this, link on https://www.hyperledger.org/projects/explorer -> join discussion on chat is wrong :)

edisinovcic (Tue, 12 Mar 2019 09:48:11 GMT):
@touchingsoil are you using docker-compose for running or ./start.sh and ./syncstart.sh scripts? You need only to modify config.json to your configuration (there are multiple configurations depending if you are using cello or composer or plain fabric). Here is the link: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/tree/release-4.0/app/platform/fabric I'm not sure about backwards compatibility, you will need to ask devs that. :)

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=QAFdFXB3NqSyCNgNf) @Aniket.1 yes. This is my file config.json { "network-configs": { "network-1": { "version": "1.0", "clients": { "client-1": { "tlsEnable": false, "organization": "Org1", "channel": "composerchannel", "credentialStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/credential", "cryptoStore": { "path": "./tmp/credentialStore_Org1/crypto" } } } }, "channels": { "composerchannel": { "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": {}, "peer1.org1.example.com": {}, "peer2.org1.example.com": {}, "peer3.org1.example.com": {} }, "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "6000", "eventHub": "6000", "eventReg": "6000" } } } } }, "organizations": { "Org1": { "mspid": "Org1MSP", "fullpath": false, "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/fps/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/composer-sample-applications-demo/packages/letters-of-credit/installer/fabric-tools/fabric-scripts/hlfv12/composer/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/keystore" }, "signedCert": { "path": "/fps/go/src/github.com/hyperledger/composer-sample-applications-demo/packages/letters-of-credit/installer/fabric-tools/fabric-scripts/hlfv12/composer/crypto-config/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/signcerts" } }, "OrdererOrg": { "mspid": "OrdererMSP", "adminPrivateKey": { "path": SashaPESIC (Sat, 16 Mar 2019 16:33:04 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=PvosKTZbXniuFdHjG) @AlbertCL locate is the command the app uses to find your chaincode files. if you are running as a standalone (outside of docker), just install mlocate and you will be fine.

nekia (Sun, 17 Mar 2019 01:50:47 GMT):
Thank you for sharing an issue you have. I've not analyzed the detail of this issue yet, but I currently recommend using docker-compose to bring up your explorer with your fabric network because deploy_explorer.sh has not been maintained, unfortunately. https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose @zhasni

zhasni (Mon, 18 Mar 2019 15:34:04 GMT):

AlbertCL (Mon, 18 Mar 2019 16:38:08 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=8FBANKjutReGi844j) @zhasni First build the docker image from source code, inside your v0.3.9.1 code do: `docker build -t hyperledger/explorer:latest . ` next `docker-compose up`

nekia (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 02:29:44 GMT):
Did you configure external network to net_byfn in your dicker-compose.yaml? @zhasni

SashaPESIC (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 07:49:27 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=05dd9066-529f-460a-975a-b480a63407a4) @nekia You do not really need to configure the external network. That only means that you have created a docker network earlier and are refering to it in the docker-compose.

FlorianStoica (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 08:58:39 GMT):
How to configure explorer docker image so that when the host restarts it automatically restart the explorer (currently had issues saying that channel already exists)

nfrunza (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 13:12:54 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aD8cd4SsmMSW3bb7h) @FlorianStoica theoretically if you restart you fabric network explorer will go down, we do not handle retries, maybe we should for some interval let say 10 min max, the question would be how do you restart your fabric, will your channels be same as before restart? if genesis hash is changes, and or crypto we would not be able to reconect.

nekia (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 13:58:34 GMT):
Let me add a little bit information. I doubt that [this configuration](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/v0.3.9.1/docker-compose.yaml#L10) doesn't align to net_byfn that is defined for first-network. If not, explorer container can't talk to the underlying fabric network.

nekia (Tue, 19 Mar 2019 13:59:03 GMT):

nfrunza (Wed, 20 Mar 2019 17:48:22 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=c6w8aP9oHhPKTARQK) @Vampire Make sure to set the environment variables CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP and CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.

nekia (Fri, 22 Mar 2019 06:52:13 GMT):
When postgres container is started the first time, the database for explorer is setup by running createdb.sh through docker-entrypoint-initdb.d

nekia (Fri, 22 Mar 2019 06:53:33 GMT):
Could you try again after doing 'docker-compose down -v' to remove all persistent volumes for explorer/explorerdb containers? @alek

Could you share the log of explorerdb container when it's started right after removing container volumes ( running docker-compose down -v ) ? And I recommend you to use v0.3.9.1 ( the latest tag ).

nfrunza (Mon, 25 Mar 2019 18:02:29 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=MiDmb9EqqCxmxpELx) @zhuquanbin Please use tag v0.3.9.1 https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/release_notes/v0.3.9.md

nfrunza (Mon, 25 Mar 2019 18:04:44 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=SopxNJth7uRWqDpXj) @kheteshrotangen see in /blockchain-explorer/logs/console, blockchain-explorer/logs/app, and blockchain-explorer/logs/db

nfrunza (Mon, 25 Mar 2019 18:06:16 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=469Fygfmuk4irBRmg) @Vampire all chaincodes that are deployed and instantiated, and discovery service enabled, - Make sure to set the environment variables ```CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP``` and ```CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT``` for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.

[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=KqE5nvpypyXfXAwPQ) @nfrunza app.log``` [2019-03-26 02:50:56.455] [DEBUG] FabricClient - Client.createUser missing required organization. nekia (Tue, 26 Mar 2019 13:31:49 GMT):
``` 2019-03-26T03:03:13.727Z - error: [Remote.js]: Error: Failed to connect before the deadline URL:grpcs://localhost:7050 ``` the hostname of orderer is still mapped to localhost even in docker environment unexpectedly. I think you need to put [this configuration](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/v0.3.9.1/docker-compose.yaml#L37) in your docker-compose.yaml? @zhuquanbin

nekia (Tue, 26 Mar 2019 13:31:49 GMT):
``` 2019-03-26T03:03:13.727Z - error: [Remote.js]: Error: Failed to connect before the deadline URL:grpcs://localhost:7050 ``` the hostname of orderer is still mapped to localhost even in docker environment unexpectedly. I think you need to put [this configuration](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/v0.3.9.1/docker-compose.yaml#L37) in your docker-compose.yaml. @zhuquanbin

zhuquanbin (Fri, 29 Mar 2019 06:03:33 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=7Sa2KNJGGNsThxuGq) @nfrunza Hi, my config.json and explorer error https://gist.github.com/zhuquanbin/76f1a1210a9c932d68b40ab8a5acd21c

nfrunza (Fri, 29 Mar 2019 13:07:23 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=w7QSe9w2ZhW77Hc8F) @kheteshrotangen Yes, it does, i think there is an interval for 1 minute, between sync with local db, please let me knoe explorer tag you use, and fabric version

nfrunza (Fri, 29 Mar 2019 13:12:35 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=pccDrnXxcyMZ5eaHd) @zhuquanbin Did you enable discovery in your fabric, and did the channel join the peer? Make sure to set the environment variables CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP and CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.

nfrunza (Fri, 29 Mar 2019 13:12:35 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=pccDrnXxcyMZ5eaHd) @zhuquanbin Did you enable discovery in your fabric (you do not have to list all the channels, only default one with discovery service enabled) and did the channel join the peer? Make sure to set the environment variables CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP and CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.

javapriyan (Tue, 02 Apr 2019 05:38:19 GMT):
```function readFileSync(config_path) { try { logger.error('config_path - :: ' + config_path); const config_loc = path.resolve(config_path); logger.error('config_loc - :: ' + config_loc); const data = fs.readFileSync(config_loc); return Buffer.from(data).toString(); } catch (err) { logger.error('NetworkConfig101 - problem reading the PEM file :: ' + err); throw err; } }```

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:15:32 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aMFbdM7W8gfFqmjb6) @Tommy109 Please let me know which explorer tag do you use and fabric version, is this composer?

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:15:32 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aMFbdM7W8gfFqmjb6) @Tommy109 Please let me know which explorer tag do you use and fabric version, is this composer?

Tommy109 (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:17:21 GMT):
@nfrunza When you say tag, is this a tag for an explorer image on docker? because I'm not using docker. I am using fabric 1.4

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:18:25 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=a9K36Rwjzy9zgAWXc) The error indicates that you have to enable DISCOVER service, https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md#fabric-network-setup , Make sure to set the environment variables CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_BOOTSTRAP and CORE_PEER_GOSSIP_EXTERNAL_ENDPOINT for each peer in the docker-compose.yaml file. These settings enable the Fabric discovery service, which is used by Hyperledger Explorer to discover the network topology.

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:20:15 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=PgJJAf8khfRz6twZa) @Tommy109 explorer has tags also,

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:20:15 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=PgJJAf8khfRz6twZa) @Tommy109 explorer has tags also, see in github under tags tab

Tommy109 (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:44:15 GMT):
@nfrunza but wouldnt I only need to set those env variables in docker-compose.yaml if I am using the docker method of setting up explorer?

nfrunza (Thu, 04 Apr 2019 12:50:52 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=aJdz2qXusYDyBbZY3) @Tommy109 you need to enable in fabric discover service, https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-1.4/discovery-overview.html

nfrunza (Mon, 08 Apr 2019 13:10:08 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=MrmFrfRvTncSrqbq8) @garunkumar450 Are you using fabric-sample as fabric network, I have noticed this when switching from one network to another, a solution would be to kill the docker and restart , docker stop $(docker ps -a -q) && docker rm -f $(docker ps -a -q) rm -rf ./crypto-config/* && rm -rf ~/.hfc*

nfrunza (Mon, 08 Apr 2019 13:13:46 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=frgJwvQaDHki5f8Qg) @PrakritiSharma i think composer is supported up to including fabric version 1.2, choose accordingly explorer version.

MatasV (Tue, 09 Apr 2019 13:39:12 GMT):
Hello, I faced some unusual problem. It seems like everything should be working properly, because there are no errors in dockers, but i'm not able to get any data from my localhost. Basicly I'm successfully bringing up Fabric network up, any of those Fabric files are not modified. Nevertheless, I'm using docker-compose to set xplorer up and *docker-compose.yaml* file are a bit modified `version: '2.0' volumes: pgdata: credentialstore: networks: mynetwork.com: external: name: artifacts_default services: explorerdb.mynetwork.com: image: hyperledger/explorer-db:0.3.8 container_name: explorerdb.mynetwork.com hostname: explorerdb.mynetwork.com environment: - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password volumes: - ./app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/createdb.sh:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/createdb.sh - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data networks: - mynetwork.com explorer.mynetwork.com: image: hyperledger/explorer:latest container_name: explorer.mynetwork.com hostname: explorer.mynetwork.com environment: - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb.mynetwork.com - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc - DATABASE_PASSWD=password - ENROLL_ID=hlbeuser - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false volumes: - ./examples/dockerConfig/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json - ./examples/dockerConfig/crypto:/tmp/crypto - credentialstore:/opt/tmp command: sh -c "sleep 16&& node /opt/explorer/main.js && tail -f /dev/null" ports: - 8090:8080 networks: - mynetwork.com `

MatasV (Tue, 09 Apr 2019 13:39:12 GMT):
Hello, I faced some unusual problem. It seems like everything should be working properly, because there are no errors in dockers, but i'm not able to get any data from my localhost. Basicly I'm successfully bringing up Fabric network up, any of those Fabric files are not modified. Nevertheless, I'm using docker-compose to set xplorer up and *docker-compose.yaml* file are a bit modified `version: '2.0' volumes: pgdata: credentialstore: networks: mynetwork.com: external: name: artifacts_default services: explorerdb.mynetwork.com: image: hyperledger/explorer-db:0.3.8 container_name: explorerdb.mynetwork.com hostname: explorerdb.mynetwork.com environment: - DATABASE_DATABASE=fabricexplorer - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc - DATABASE_PASSWORD=password volumes: - ./app/persistence/fabric/postgreSQL/db/createdb.sh:/docker-entrypoint-initdb.d/createdb.sh - pgdata:/var/lib/postgresql/data networks: - mynetwork.com explorer.mynetwork.com: image: hyperledger/explorer:latest container_name: explorer.mynetwork.com hostname: explorer.mynetwork.com environment: - DATABASE_HOST=explorerdb.mynetwork.com - DATABASE_USERNAME=hppoc - DATABASE_PASSWD=password - ENROLL_ID=hlbeuser - DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false volumes: - ./examples/dockerConfig/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json - ./examples/dockerConfig/crypto:/tmp/crypto - credentialstore:/opt/tmp command: sh -c "sleep 16&& node /opt/explorer/main.js && tail -f /dev/null" ports: - 8090:8080 networks: - mynetwork.com ` I have checked db logs and it looks like that all of those peers are successfully connected. nfrunza (Tue, 09 Apr 2019 15:00:44 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=PAg4D7EKGvNu6jFEv) @MatasV see sample configuration in https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/examples/net1/README.md#example-of-running-be-with-fabric-network

nekia (Wed, 10 Apr 2019 00:59:47 GMT):
I think the URL of each peer in your config.json should be hostname which is resolved inside the docker and you don't also need to use the published port number to host machine. ``` "peer1.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer1.org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpc://localhost:8051", <<-- grpcs://peer1.org1.example.com:7051 "eventUrl": "grpc://localhost:8053", <<-- grpcs://peer1.org1.example.com:7053 "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer1.org1.example.com" } }, ```

nekia (Wed, 10 Apr 2019 01:00:10 GMT):
@MatasV

Has joined the channel.

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 16:51:30 GMT):
Hi so i am trying to connect hyperledger blockexplorer with fabric network that contains 3 organizations and 1 peer for each organization. Now I am configuring the explorer such that I am adding only 1 organization in config.json under "organizations" object. The idea is that in a consortium all the participating organizations would have their separate nodes and they would not share the private keys among themselves. So for each organization there would be a separate instance of explorer, is this right approach?

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 16:54:24 GMT):
also if i do it this way, everything seems fine in explorer except that only the peers of the organization i have added in the config file are shows as running and all the other peers are shown as down. Is this normal behaviour? Why is it showing those peers down when clearly it is detecting those peers. Also for the second instance the same peer is in running state and others are down.

mssathees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 16:56:47 GMT):
Are there any players (Companies) available with blockchain based solution in Surety bond industry, specifically in North America

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 17:03:20 GMT):
So in the end this is how my three version of explorer appear for each organization

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 17:03:38 GMT):

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 17:03:38 GMT):

orgs2.PNG

MujtabaIdrees (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 17:03:40 GMT):

orgs.PNG

nfrunza (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 21:12:57 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=5xjqfTH6d5t93Fsxo) @MujtabaIdrees If each node has their own cryptos, i believe you need 3 separates

nfrunza (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 21:12:57 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=5xjqfTH6d5t93Fsxo) @MujtabaIdrees If each node has their own cryptos, i believe you need 3 separate eplorer, as you do not want to enable discovery service across nodes

nfrunza (Thu, 11 Apr 2019 21:12:57 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=5xjqfTH6d5t93Fsxo) @MujtabaIdrees If each node has their own cryptos, i believe you need 3 separate explorer, as you do not want to enable discovery service across nodes
