jrasm91 (Tue, 28 Jul 2020 23:45:33 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

jrasm91 (Tue, 28 Jul 2020 23:45:34 GMT):
Hello. I'm using the latest version of explorer with fabric and I'm seeing the transaction _values_ of the read/write sets as a buffer. Is this expected, or am I doing something wrong? With the node-sdk, using `channel.queryTransaction(txId)` from `fabric-client 1.4.8` I see the read/write set showing up as a string, as I would expect. I'm not sure why I am seeing a different result with explorer.

jrasm91 (Tue, 28 Jul 2020 23:46:18 GMT):

Clipboard - July 28, 2020 4:45 PM

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:28:06 GMT):
No, fabric CA user which you need to set in connection profile for Explorer must have `admin` attribute in `hf.Registrar.Roles`.

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:31:14 GMT):
Because Explorer need `admin` when accessing chaincode information on Fabric network (although it basically depends on the configuration of Fabric network).

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:34:54 GMT):
Could you provide more detail of your issue? The version of Explorer/Fabric you're using, the steps to reproduce the issue, etc.

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:38:18 GMT):
Thank you for sharing the issue. We'll see if the issue is recreated our side.

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:41:19 GMT):
In the latest fabric Node.js sdk, work of data unmarshalling of the result returned from API are left to user, not SDK. It might be causing the issue.

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:41:19 GMT):
In the latest fabric Node.js sdk (fabric-network), work of data unmarshalling of the result returned from API are left to user, not SDK. It might be causing the issue.

nekia (Wed, 29 Jul 2020 08:51:32 GMT):
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-790

HLFPOC (Thu, 30 Jul 2020 04:49:51 GMT):
Can we leverage explorer REST APIs and pull the network information to show in a custom UI? If yes, what would be the approach to do the same ?

touchingsoil (Thu, 30 Jul 2020 07:53:53 GMT):

nekia (Thu, 30 Jul 2020 12:15:01 GMT):
Yes, I think, you can. You can try it out on `http://localhost:8080/api-docs`.

nekia (Fri, 31 Jul 2020 14:16:46 GMT):
https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/fabric-sdk-node?msg=acq5JimKYGYmSPWGd

nekia (Fri, 31 Jul 2020 14:22:24 GMT):
It's based on the specification of fabric-sdk-node. Please refer the above link for detail. We're considering if we should add a new option to leave choices to Explorer users for switching the represent format of read/write set value among 'Buffer array(default)', 'String value.toString('utf-8')' or 'Hex value.toString('hex')'.

AshutoshKumar7 (Sun, 09 Aug 2020 09:49:36 GMT):

nekia (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 05:46:50 GMT):
Great! What was the cause of your previous issue?

nekia (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 05:52:58 GMT):
Please try it again after delete all volumes mounted to Explorer container. Explorer stores credentials you configured in connection profile into a wallet on its local file system. If Explorer is still referring old stored credential even after Fabric network restarted, this `access denied` error can be happened.

nekia (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 05:54:16 GMT):
What does `network link does not work` mean?

nekia (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 06:04:26 GMT):
Thank you for update. We'll consider adding a new configuration to customize base route path to Explorer.

nekia (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 06:24:25 GMT):
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-801

bassemmkh (Mon, 10 Aug 2020 13:35:00 GMT):

carlosalca (Tue, 11 Aug 2020 05:59:34 GMT):

carlosalca (Tue, 11 Aug 2020 06:00:30 GMT):

carlosalca (Tue, 11 Aug 2020 06:02:28 GMT):
Is this new athentication supporting ACL to the network ? I mean If all users can see everything in the network or only their stuff?

nekia (Wed, 12 Aug 2020 08:55:30 GMT):
Yes, explorer should work with fabric 2.2

nekia (Wed, 12 Aug 2020 13:20:25 GMT):
No it's not supporting ACL. Each user can see all data within the organisation the user belongs.

nekia (Thu, 13 Aug 2020 11:36:21 GMT):
:information_source: *v1.1.2 has been released* # New Features * Add user management feature/API. Please refer [README-CONFIG.md](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/4bc2a9ed2145b299b44c3efb4467de5ac116aa8f/README-CONFIG.md#user-management) for detail * Reduce container image size (942MB -> 174MB) * Add fabric 1.4.8 / 2.2.0 support * Change default encode of value in TX details. Please refer [README-CONFIG.md](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/4bc2a9ed2145b299b44c3efb4467de5ac116aa8f/README-CONFIG.md#value-encoding-in-transaction-details) for detail * Update example of connection profile for docker setup # Bug Fixes and Updates * Fix typos in "SyncService" * Fix typo in "Transaction Details" view * Correct index to get validation code from metadata https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/releases/tag/v1.1.2 https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/explorer/tags 1.1.2 https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/explorer-db/tags 1.1.2 If you have any feature requests or any interests for contribution, please feel free to reach us. We would be glad. :slight_smile: Cheers

fmoca (Mon, 24 Aug 2020 12:29:23 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

RobinKlemens (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:33:04 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

RobinKlemens (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:33:04 GMT):
Hi everyone. Is there a way to run hyperledger-explorer without the private key of org admin? Hyperledger-explorer provides the feature of `Monitoring multiple organizations`(https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#monitoring-multiple-organizations). If the connection profiles of every org require the adminPrivateKeys all admin credential would be stored at a single place which I want to avoid. How do you asses the security risk of the overall hyperledger fabric network when running hyperledger-explorer with multiple organizations?

RobinKlemens (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:33:04 GMT):
Hi everyone. Is there a way to run hyperledger-explorer without private key of org admin?

tongli (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:40:51 GMT):
@RobinKlemens take a look at minifabric which sets up everything easily including using explorer.

tongli (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:43:07 GMT):
The idea is that each org manages their own nodes. In a real production env, I do not think two orgs will share one machine for things and will share their admin/private keys. Each org will hold their own keys. Explorer user from one org should only be able to use their own admin key to see what is on the network.

tongli (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 11:45:31 GMT):
You see the cases that multiple orgs have keys on the single machine due to these setups are all test env or dev env. Real production env would not have multiple org peers or orderers running on one machine, these keys will not be altogether neither.

RobinKlemens (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 13:45:22 GMT):
Thanks for your response @tongli . Alright, I agree to the point that in production env every org would host there own infrastructure. For sure the peers and orderer and hyperledger-explorer instances as well. Still, the private key of an admin is required. As far as I understand hyperledger-explorer it uses service discovery to retrieve information of the network. But wouldn't a private key of a client be enough (e.g. explorer client with affiliations such as org1.explorer)? I don't want to store the private key of the admin in the explorer container.

tongli (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 15:33:22 GMT):
@RobinKlemens I am not an explorer expert, but when I added explorer to minifabric, I remember you just need to configure the container to use the private key. Do not think explorer expose the private key any where, but in any case, since explorer use the key in theory, you will have to secure the explorer itself.

RobinKlemens (Tue, 25 Aug 2020 15:42:41 GMT):
@tongli I don't think explorer exposes the private key. And yes, the explorer container needs extra security as long as the private key of the admin is required. I'd love to get some additional information about this from the maintainers. Best Robin

nekia (Wed, 26 Aug 2020 01:36:30 GMT):
We're using a wallet to store an identity (certificate and private key) on a machine where Explorer is running.

nekia (Wed, 26 Aug 2020 01:39:27 GMT):
If using HSM wallet and providing a pin to access the HSM from a secret artifactory, it might be more secure.

nekia (Wed, 26 Aug 2020 01:43:26 GMT):
In this case we also need using Fabric-CA to retrieve an admin identity for avoiding to pass a plain private key to Explorer.

bh4rtp (Mon, 31 Aug 2020 08:35:59 GMT):

Error: Endorser must be connected explorer.example.com | [2020-09-01T02:47:33.601] [ERROR] FabricClient - { ExplorerError: [ 'Failed to create wallet, please check the configuration, and valid file paths' ] explorer.example.com | at FabricGateway.initialize (/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js:135:10) explorer.example.com | at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) explorer.example.com | name: 'ExplorerError', explorer.example.com | message: explorer.example.com | '[ \'Failed to create wallet, please check the configuration, and valid file paths\' ]' } explorer.example.com | [2020-09-01T02:47:33.603] [ERROR] main - Received kill signal, shutting down gracefully explorer.example.com | [2020-09-01T02:47:35.607] [INFO] main - Closed out connections explorer.example.com exited with code 1```

bh4rtp (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 02:53:38 GMT):
i noticed that explorer using discovery enabled = true, so how to fix these errors.

nekia (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:10:21 GMT):
Which version of Explorer are you using ?

nekia (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:13:16 GMT):
The url of each peer seems to be mapped to localhost. Please have a look at the following configuration (`- DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false`)in your `docker-compose.yml` https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose

nekia (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:13:36 GMT):
@bh4rtp

bh4rtp (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:20:38 GMT):
@nekia i am using 1.1.2 release. and my network is built locally by docker containers.

bh4rtp (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:21:24 GMT):
should i set DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=true?

bh4rtp (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:23:19 GMT):
and i suggest that the discovery service should be disabled or can be configured, i.e. discovery: { enabled: false}, in the explorer.

nekia (Tue, 01 Sep 2020 03:38:55 GMT):
You should set `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST=false`. And please make sure peer url in your connection profile is configured correctly, that means the url should be kinda hostname valid within your docker network instead of localhost.

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 02:42:29 GMT):
@nekia solved. i configured the error network for `explorer` and `explorer-db`, mistook '-' as '.'.:grinning:

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 02:42:29 GMT):
@nekia discovery problems solved.

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 03:35:10 GMT):
in the docker-compose.yaml, i comment the command line for `explorer`, why does the explorer still start to run when docker-compose up?

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 04:37:57 GMT):

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 06:29:00 GMT):
finally get the explorer running. but login failed. which user and password should i use to login the explorer?

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 06:54:37 GMT):
my client configurations: ```"client": { "tlsEnable": true, "caCredential": { "id": "admin", "password": "adminpw" }, "adminCredential": { "id": "exploreradmin", "password": "exploreradminpw" }, "enableAuthentication": true, "organization": "Org1MSP", "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "6000", "eventHub": "6000", "eventReg": "6000" }, "orderer": "6000" } } }```

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 06:55:25 GMT):

bh4rtp (Wed, 02 Sep 2020 07:09:42 GMT):

nekia (Thu, 03 Sep 2020 07:41:25 GMT):
@bh4rtp As described in [README-CONFIG | Uing Fabric CA](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#using-fabric-ca), you need to specify affiliation to be used for Admin credential, too

bh4rtp (Thu, 03 Sep 2020 08:55:24 GMT):
@nekia yes. i specified an affiliation, i.e. org1.department1. but i don't know where org1.department1 is set to be an admin in the ca-server configuration yaml.

bh4rtp (Thu, 03 Sep 2020 14:48:15 GMT):
@nekia my network is created by `cryptogen` tool. should i use certificates and not ca authorities for configuration of connection profile?

nekia (Thu, 03 Sep 2020 14:58:08 GMT):
Yes, you should because it's easier for configuration to use generated credentials. Once you can see Explorer is working fine, then you can try using fabric CA again.

nekia (Thu, 03 Sep 2020 15:03:06 GMT):
Caveat: if you make any mistake on fabric CA once, you need to delete your wallet and restart your fabric CA server because incorrect identity has already been registered to the server and stored in your wallet. @bh4rtp

bh4rtp (Fri, 04 Sep 2020 01:03:51 GMT):
@nekia successfully got the explorer running now. thanks.

bh4rtp (Fri, 04 Sep 2020 01:05:34 GMT):
if i set `"enableAuthentication": true`, should i login in the explorer using exploreradmin/exploreradminpwd？

nekia (Fri, 04 Sep 2020 02:46:54 GMT):
Yes, you can use id/password you specify in the connection profile. You can also register a new user which is used for login, via GUI/API.

bh4rtp (Fri, 04 Sep 2020 03:36:36 GMT):
i cannot login. it tells invalid user or password. so i set enableAuthentication = false.

nekia (Fri, 04 Sep 2020 05:32:03 GMT):
In example of README, password for admin is `exploreradminpw`, not `exploreradminpwd`. Please make sure that for just in case you're using incorrect password.

jorgeRodriguez (Sun, 06 Sep 2020 07:33:32 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

aditya520 (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 05:55:38 GMT):
The certificate authority mentioned in the orgs is not present in the connection profile. Moreover the paths you provided should not direct to your local filesystem, it should direct to docker mounted volumes. I highly recommend you to go through this https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md

aditya520 (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 05:55:38 GMT):
The certificate authority mentioned in the orgs is not present in the connection profile. Moreover the paths you provided should not direct to your local filesystem, it should direct to docker mounted volumes. I highly recommend you to go through this https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README.md :grinning:

aditya520 (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 07:56:02 GMT):
@nekia Q2. Can I increase the discovery timeout which is by default 3000 from config file?

Amanullah68 (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 08:13:32 GMT):

Screenshot from 2020-09-09 13-13-13.png

Amanullah68 (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 08:13:44 GMT):

Screenshot from 2020-09-09 13-13-13.png

nekia (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 14:24:04 GMT):
Q1 No you can't. The list on Explorer completely depends on the result from service discovery. You can see the result by executing discover CLI by yourself.

nekia (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 14:24:06 GMT):
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-2.2/discovery-cli.html

nekia (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 14:36:43 GMT):
Q2 No you can't. If you're mentioning the timeout on your log, I think it depends on the settings of grpc. You might be able to override it by connection profile. ``` "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { "url": "grpcs://localhost:7051", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com" } ```

nekia (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 14:36:43 GMT):
Q2 No you can't. If you're mentioning the timeout on your log, I think it depends on the settings of grpc. You might be able to override it by connection profile. ``` "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { ... "url": "grpcs://localhost:7051", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com", "grpc-wait-for-ready-timeout": 3000 <<<< } ```

nekia (Wed, 09 Sep 2020 14:36:43 GMT):
Q2 No you can't. If you're mentioning the timeout on your log, I think it depends on the settings of grpc. You might be able to override it by connection profile, but I've never tried it. ``` "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { ... "url": "grpcs://localhost:7051", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com", "grpc-wait-for-ready-timeout": 3000 <<<< } ```

nekia (Thu, 10 Sep 2020 06:04:35 GMT):
It seems that your connection profile is incorrect. You're specifying cert file with path of host side, not one of container.

nekia (Thu, 10 Sep 2020 11:50:29 GMT):
In the last snapshot, I can see `localhost` in url of `peer0.shippe...`. It's incorrect. You need to specify a hostname which is valid in your docker network (it's probably `my-network_byfn`, I guess). It's worthwhile to use the utility @saanvijay suggestes https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=My2oPd9RoJa7RJwNF

nekia (Fri, 11 Sep 2020 02:08:14 GMT):
Please check log and make sure Explorer container belongs to the same docker network with your fabric network `docker network inspect [your network]`

Received type undefined explorer.example.com | at Object.openSync (fs.js:435:3) explorer.example.com | at Object.readFileSync (fs.js:343:35) explorer.example.com | at FabricGateway.enrollCaIdentity (/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js:189:25) explorer.example.com | at FabricGateway.initialize (/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/gateway/FabricGateway.js:79:27)```

sigma67 (Tue, 15 Sep 2020 13:07:11 GMT):
So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js: `` 177 2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z 2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z 2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z

sigma67 (Tue, 15 Sep 2020 13:07:11 GMT):
So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js: ``` 177 2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z 2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z 2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z ```

sigma67 (Tue, 15 Sep 2020 13:07:11 GMT):
So I'm not sure of the best way to communicate this, but I've found an oddity with the transaction timestamps in the code of SyncService.js. It seems that the timestamp of the first transaction in the block is assigned to **all** transactions in that block. In l.486 the block timestamp is defined as the timestamp of the first tx in the block, and thereafter this variable is reused for **every tx** in the for loop starting in l. 503. It is finally committed to the database in l.631. However, each transaction actually has a unique timestamp that differs based on when it was created. See the following example for block 177 in my test blockchain, which was created by adding some logging output to SyncService.js after modifying it to include the correct timestamps - previously the timestamps would all be equal to the first: ``` 177 2020-09-15T12:22:28.863Z 2020-09-15T12:22:28.935Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.000Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.069Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.631Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.708Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.796Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.873Z 2020-09-15T12:22:29.948Z 2020-09-15T12:22:30.023Z ```

sigma67 (Tue, 15 Sep 2020 13:12:47 GMT):
If someone can confirm that this is not intentional I could open an issue on JIRA and submit a PR?

jeevasang (Wed, 16 Sep 2020 05:30:27 GMT):
Please create Jira and submit a PR

jeevasang (Wed, 16 Sep 2020 05:53:11 GMT):

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 01:48:11 GMT):
Thank you for reporting issue @tongli

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 01:55:22 GMT):
Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on guest OS when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers.

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 01:55:22 GMT):
Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on local Docker host when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers.

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 01:55:22 GMT):
Explorer assumes that all peers are running as container on local Docker host when `DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST` is set to `true` and `localhost` is assigned across all peers as `fabric-samples/test-network` is.

bh4rtp (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 01:57:31 GMT):
it seems that explorer only accepts path configuration of tlsCACerts.

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:00:00 GMT):
Otherwise, Explorer will count all peers which have different port with same IP address (except 127.0.0.1, localhost) as a single peer.

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:02:20 GMT):
pem format is also supported by Explorer in v1.1.1 or later. FYI

bh4rtp (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:05:59 GMT):
i just changed all pem to path for ca profile, otherwise it reports path not configured.

bh4rtp (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:06:29 GMT):

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:17:44 GMT):
This conversion happens inside fabric-sdk-node. [fabric-network gateway.connect DiscoveryOption settings](https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-2.2/tutorial-discovery-fabric-network.html)

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:17:44 GMT):
This address mapping between localhost:port and each url happens inside fabric-sdk-node. [fabric-network gateway.connect DiscoveryOption settings](https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-2.2/tutorial-discovery-fabric-network.html)

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:20:25 GMT):
We don't have example for that in our tutorial yet

nekia (Thu, 17 Sep 2020 02:21:26 GMT):
But there are some connection profiles used for our end-to-end test environment https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/app/platform/fabric/e2e-test/configs/connection-profile/org1-network.json

yashumunsharma (Wed, 23 Sep 2020 12:36:21 GMT):
*Explorer Block syncing Issue with Kubernetes setup* *Current Configuration: * We are using latest version of explorer and version of fabric is 1.4.2 with private data collection. In network configuration, We have 3 channel network setup with 4 organization in each channel and some of them are common among them. We have created one explorer profile of an organization which is part of all the channels. *Issue:* Explorer works fine for few hours of its deployment in Kubernetes but after some time dashboard, blocks and transactions are not getting updated with the blockchain network. We have also observed that in network page ledger height is getting updated all the time but other than this nothing is getting updated. But redeploying the pods of explorer help us getting everything into sync again for some time.

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 00:14:07 GMT):
@tongli User management function doesn't require fabric ca configuration. Identities for additional users except admin have been managed with ID/PASSWORD manner.

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 00:16:32 GMT):
The configurations mentioned in the following page are mandatory to make use of fabric ca in Explorer. https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#using-fabric-ca

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:08:00 GMT):
@nekia so the user registration function of explorer is really just a function to register a user to use Explorer, these users have nothing to do with Fabric network itself or any CA node, is that correct?

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:17:55 GMT):
this bug has been filed for awhile, no activity at all.

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:17:57 GMT):
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-829?filter=-2

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:18:04 GMT):
can someone please take a look at this?

sigma67 (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:20:07 GMT):
I don't think Explorer is meant to manage fabric-ca users, that's probably more within the scope of the Cello project (monitoring vs. managing/operating)

sigma67 (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:20:39 GMT):
Ofc it would be great to have both in one app, but right now they're two distinct projects with different goals

sigma67 (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:27:25 GMT):
It seems it's actually part of the project, but still in design phase: https://github.com/hyperledger/cello/issues/118 -> #cello

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:49:55 GMT):
Yes, that's correct.

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:53:36 GMT):
I left a comment, Explorer expects that peer has been assigned 127.0.0.1 in such an environment each peer is running as a container on the same host machine with Explorer.

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 13:54:02 GMT):
Is it acceptable for you to change IP address?

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 14:29:22 GMT):
@nekia, not really. It could be a multi host env.

tongli (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 14:30:12 GMT):
For example, some nodes run on one machine and some run on other machines. Ports are important part of running app, explorer should not make assumption like that.

nekia (Thu, 24 Sep 2020 22:49:53 GMT):
OK, I understand. We'll look into it.

sigma67 (Mon, 05 Oct 2020 09:18:44 GMT):
Two comments regarding the typescript migration: 1) typescript is not yet a dependency and 2) it seems the "npm run build" needs to be added to the main.sh install script, so it runs the necessary Typescript compilation After I did those 2 steps it worked for me :)

sigma67 (Mon, 05 Oct 2020 09:18:44 GMT):
One small comment regarding the typescript migration. It seems the "npm run build" needs to be added to the main.sh install script, so it runs the necessary Typescript compilation. After I did that it worked for me :)

nekia (Tue, 06 Oct 2020 07:16:38 GMT):
You're right. Thanks. We'll update it later on. Currently user needs to do like that or do command like `npm run start`.

pouya (Tue, 13 Oct 2020 08:44:16 GMT):
hi every one. I am using Explorer v1.1.3 containerized with Fabric 1.4.7 and it is my view: 1- users need to have the ability to change their passwords. 2- sometimes Explorer doesn't work properly although has no error log. (it only shows peer nodes and need to restart the container multiple times to works properly) 3- explorer should works without having channel section in its connection.json and should collects channel information by itself. 4- the chaincode section is not working properly. (chaincode instantiated on channel "a" also is shown in channel "b") @nekia

pouya (Tue, 13 Oct 2020 08:44:16 GMT):
hi every one. I am using Explorer v1.1.3 containerized with Fabric 1.4.7 and it is my view: 1- users need to have the ability to change their passwords. 2- sometimes Explorer doesn't work properly in the starting time, although has no error log. (it only shows peer nodes and need to restart the container multiple times to works properly) 3- explorer should works without having channel section in its connection.json and should collects channel information by itself. 4- the chaincode section is not working properly. (chaincode instantiated on channel "a" also is shown in channel "b") @nekia

sigma67 (Tue, 13 Oct 2020 16:19:44 GMT):
Regarding 2), there are definitely error logs available in the `logs` folder

nekia (Sat, 31 Oct 2020 04:56:54 GMT):
There seem to be a certificate issue. Please make sure that the certificate is referable correctly on the Explorer container. @rohithkumar

rohithkumar (Sat, 31 Oct 2020 10:28:51 GMT):
refering the same certificate which generated for fabric...and the certificate is also placed in the correct path....

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 12:17:24 GMT):
I think you need to rebuild the docker images with the latest changes in git.. so that this certificate checking version is backward compatible

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:20:04 GMT):
What version of cryptogen are you using when creating your crypto artifacts?

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:21:32 GMT):
am using 1.4.4 fabric... might be there is mis configuration of cryptogen

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:21:39 GMT):
what version do explorer supports

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:21:56 GMT):
i cant change certificates of fabric now for explorer

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:29:27 GMT):
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/BE-768?focusedCommentId=69657&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels%3Acomment-tabpanel#comment-69657

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:30:43 GMT):
The same issue has already been reported.

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:31:24 GMT):
yes..but do the fix is updated in the docker image of 1.1.3

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:33:22 GMT):

Clipboard - November 1, 2020 7:02 PM

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:33:34 GMT):
do my understanding right?

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:38:03 GMT):
The solution for the issue BE-768 I pointed above is updating cryptogen tool to v1.4.0 or later.

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:38:54 GMT):
I guess the issue you're facing now is nothing to do with the recent changes.

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:39:07 GMT):
it should be backward compatible... when fabric is running with backward compatible certificates...

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:43:37 GMT):
it's a compatibility issue of node.js. In Node.js v10 or later, version of openssl seems to be updated to v1.1.

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:45:07 GMT):
ok then i need to regenerate the certificates using latest cryptogen and try for explorer?

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:45:51 GMT):
Old format of certificate generated by old cryptgen is not allowed in openssl v1.1 or later.

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:46:02 GMT):
Yes

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:46:59 GMT):
ok will try

rohithkumar (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:47:32 GMT):
thanks for the support and will come back if i face any issues

nekia (Sun, 01 Nov 2020 13:48:18 GMT):
:thumbsup:

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Mon, 02 Nov 2020 12:34:29 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Mon, 02 Nov 2020 12:34:29 GMT):
Dear all, I have a doubt regarding the *minimum system requirements for hyperledger explorer*. I am using a system with 4GB RAM and 80 GB SSD. I am using the hyperledger explorer docker images with tag 1.1.2 *When I run the _top_ command* , I see a process with random name consuming 197% of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715100-46477d80-1ac2-11eb-92a3-a121e512d81e.png) *output of _docker stats_: *shows hyperleger explorer db service is consuming 197 % of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715625-ebfaec80-1ac2-11eb-993c-2e5c15b391ed.png) I am not sure whether that random process is linked with hyperledger_explorer_db container. If I remove the hyperledger explorer services, the random process disappears and CPU utilization and memory becomes normal . I initially thought my system was under DDoS Trojan attacks as specified here https://admin-ahead.com/forum/server-security-hardening/unix-trojan-ddos_xor-1-chinese-chicken-multiplatform-dos-botnets-trojan/ But now i doubt that the random process is linked with hyperledger explorer db. Why hyperledger explorer db docker container is starting a random process in the host machine and consumes 190 % of CPU and 60 % memory. ? I would require help for the following questions : - Does anyone have experienced this behavior when using hyperledger explorer ? - Is this a normal behaviour of hyperledger explorer db docker services to consume this much CPU and memory ? - What is the minimum system requirements to run hyperledger explorer docker services Thanks & regards, Anand

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Mon, 02 Nov 2020 12:34:29 GMT):
Dear all, I have a doubt regarding the *minimum system requirements for hyperledger explorer*. I am using a system with 4GB RAM and 80 GB SSD. I am using the hyperledger explorer docker images with tag 1.1.2 *When I run the _top_ command* , I see a process with random name consuming 197% of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715100-46477d80-1ac2-11eb-92a3-a121e512d81e.png) *output of _docker stats_: *shows hyperleger explorer db service is consuming 197 % of CPU and 60% of memory (https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/30879156/97715625-ebfaec80-1ac2-11eb-993c-2e5c15b391ed.png) I am not sure whether that random process is linked with hyperledger_explorer_db container. If I remove the hyperledger explorer services, the random process disappears and CPU utilization and memory becomes normal . I initially thought my system was under DDoS Trojan attacks as specified here https://admin-ahead.com/forum/server-security-hardening/unix-trojan-ddos_xor-1-chinese-chicken-multiplatform-dos-botnets-trojan/ But now i doubt that the random process is linked with hyperledger explorer db. *I would require help for the following questions : * - Why hyperledger explorer db docker container is starting a random process in the host machine and consumes 190 % of CPU and 60 % memory? Has anyone experienced this behavior when using hyperledger explorer ? - Is this a normal behaviour of hyperledger explorer db docker services to consume this much CPU and memory ? - What is the minimum system requirements to run hyperledger explorer docker services Thanks & regards, Anand

But explorer pod got restarted continuously without throwing any error logs. I checked the explorer pod logs. The following are the logs fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.11/main/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.11/community/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz (1/5) Installing ca-certificates (20191127-r2) (2/5) Installing c-ares (1.15.0-r0) (3/5) Installing nghttp2-libs (1.40.0-r1) (4/5) Installing libuv (1.34.0-r0) (5/5) Installing nodejs-current (13.1.0-r0) Executing busybox-1.31.1-r9.trigger Executing ca-certificates-20191127-r2.trigger OK: 60 MiB in 21 packages v10.19.0 The command which I used to start explorer pod, cd /opt/explorer node $EXPLORER_APP_PATH/main.js && tail -f /dev/null Can anyone suggest how to resolve this?

The following are the logs fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.11/main/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz fetch http://dl-cdn.alpinelinux.org/alpine/v3.11/community/x86_64/APKINDEX.tar.gz (1/5) Installing ca-certificates (20191127-r2) (2/5) Installing c-ares (1.15.0-r0) (3/5) Installing nghttp2-libs (1.40.0-r1) (4/5) Installing libuv (1.34.0-r0) (5/5) Installing nodejs-current (13.1.0-r0) Executing busybox-1.31.1-r9.trigger Executing ca-certificates-20191127-r2.trigger OK: 60 MiB in 21 packages v10.19.0 The command which I used to start explorer pod, cd /opt/explorer node $EXPLORER_APP_PATH/main.js && tail -f /dev/null Can anyone suggest how to resolve this?

CaJIbHuK (Mon, 23 Nov 2020 15:08:59 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

nekia (Wed, 25 Nov 2020 00:29:02 GMT):
Hi @Vgkmanju First, I recommend you using the latest explorer container image (1.1.3). And the log you shared seems to be nothing to do with Explorer runtime log. I guess it's like a log while building a docker container image, but I'm not sure.

nekia (Wed, 25 Nov 2020 01:18:14 GMT):
In that case, you don't need to specify/override command for Explorer container. And also need to update your connection profile which is consumed by Explorer to the new syntax. Please refer [here](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md) for the detail.

piyushmaheshwari65 (Wed, 25 Nov 2020 04:13:36 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

dongge531 (Wed, 25 Nov 2020 10:10:05 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

dongge531 (Wed, 25 Nov 2020 10:11:00 GMT):
This error log is continuously printed on the console, though the mentioned node, orderer1-ProCoop , appeared on the web page。 What's wrong with it?

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:45:30 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:51:47 GMT):
These three error log are repeatedly printed on the console, though the mentioned node, orderer1-ProCoop, appeared on the Explorer web page. Please tell me what's wrong with it.

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:52:44 GMT):

explorer.png

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:53:20 GMT):

explorer.png

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:55:30 GMT):

explorer.png

nike (Thu, 26 Nov 2020 14:59:31 GMT):

logs.png

nekia (Sat, 28 Nov 2020 10:21:30 GMT):
Hi @nike It seems to be kind of network issue that is reported in the following JIRA of fabric-sdk-node. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1646 This error is incurred sometime when multiple transaction are raced. So far this error doesn't give any major effects to Explorer.

nekia (Sat, 28 Nov 2020 10:23:42 GMT):
The fix of this issue has already been introduced into the latest fabric-network package, but it's introduced another issue as below. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1663?jql=project%20%3D%20FABN%20AND%20text%20~%20%22system%20chaincode%22

nekia (Sat, 28 Nov 2020 10:23:42 GMT):
The fix of this issue has already been introduced into the latest fabric-network package, but it's introduced another issue as below. https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1663

nekia (Sat, 28 Nov 2020 10:24:17 GMT):
So we have to wait for the next release 2.2.4.

nekia (Sat, 28 Nov 2020 10:24:17 GMT):
So we have to wait for the next release 2.2.4 of fabric-network package.

nike (Mon, 30 Nov 2020 04:59:03 GMT):
[ ](https://chat.hyperledger.org/channel/hyperledger-explorer?msg=ryfJKpowh9JbCgEiv) :ok_hand: thank you very much

CaJIbHuK (Wed, 02 Dec 2020 14:49:21 GMT):

chanjaljayaram (Tue, 08 Dec 2020 15:55:03 GMT):
Has anyone tried Explorer v1.1.3 with Fabric 2.3.0? The release notes says v1.1.3 supports Fabric 1.4.0 - 2.2.0. I'm trying to get Explorer v1.1.3 working with Fabric 2.3.0. I've mTLS enabled in the Fabric network and I've set client.clientTlsIdentity in the Explorer connection-profile. The initial connections with the peer works. But after a while I find Explorer generating a self-signed certificate to make the connection, and all the subsequent connections after this fails.

bh4rtp (Tue, 08 Dec 2020 23:39:16 GMT):
yes. v1.1.3 does support fabric 2.3.0.

chanjaljayaram (Wed, 09 Dec 2020 04:10:44 GMT):

bh4rtp (Wed, 09 Dec 2020 23:59:05 GMT):
it seems to be certificate error. you can check the connection-profile, I think you used the wrong tls certificates.

nekia (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 07:28:39 GMT):
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/commit/2902885d8c28a629c3450e62a5d73af3e181fa03

nekia (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 07:30:16 GMT):
v1.1.3 has above issue for mTLS. It's fixed in the latest master. Can you use the container image locally rebuilt instead? @chanjaljayaram

chanjaljayaram (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 08:42:18 GMT):
Thanks Nekia... I was finally able to get it working with the below updates:``` 1) I was missing the setting of DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST to false ``` ``` 2) in FabricGateway.js I see the client.setTlsClientCertAndKey() being called. I changed it to client.setTlsClientCertAndKey(channel.client._tls_mutual.clientCert,channel.client._tls_mutual.clientKey); ``` ``` Is that the fix in the master branch? ```

chanjaljayaram (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 08:42:18 GMT):
Thanks Nekia... I was finally able to get it working with the below updates:``` 1) I was missing the setting of DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST to false ``` ``` 2) in FabricGateway.js I see the client.setTlsClientCertAndKey() being called. I changed it to client.setTlsClientCertAndKey(channel.client._tls_mutual.clientCert,channel.client._tls_mutual.clientKey); ``` Is that the fix in the master branch?

chanjaljayaram (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 08:42:18 GMT):
Thanks Nekia... I was finally able to get it working with the below updates:``` 1) I was missing the setting of DISCOVERY_AS_LOCALHOST to false 2) in FabricGateway.js I see the client.setTlsClientCertAndKey() being called. I changed it to client.setTlsClientCertAndKey(channel.client._tls_mutual.clientCert,channel.client._tls_mutual.clientKey); ``` Is that the fix in the master branch?

chanjaljayaram (Thu, 10 Dec 2020 08:44:33 GMT):
Nekia, never mind... I see the updates in the link that you shared... thanks

nekia (Fri, 11 Dec 2020 12:48:02 GMT):
Can you delete the persistence volume of your fabric CA once? If you're trying to start Explorer several times with same fabric network environment and you lost the wallet which an identity generated by fabric CA is stored

nekia (Fri, 11 Dec 2020 12:48:02 GMT):
Can you delete the persistence volume of your fabric CA once? If you're trying to start Explorer several times with same fabric network environment and you lost the wallet which an identity generated by fabric CA is stored is deleted by mistake, this error (Identity is already registered) can be happened.

nekia (Fri, 11 Dec 2020 12:51:09 GMT):
Can you delete the persistence volume of your fabric CA once? If you're trying to start Explorer several times with same fabric network environment and you lost the wallet which an identity generated by fabric CA is stored is deleted by mistake, this error (Identity is already registered) can be happened.

nekia (Fri, 11 Dec 2020 12:53:07 GMT):
Or please change admin ID from `abc3` to other new one.

nekia (Fri, 11 Dec 2020 12:53:07 GMT):
Or please change admin ID of Explorer from `abc3` to other new one.

greg2git (Sun, 20 Dec 2020 00:32:56 GMT):

greg2git (Sun, 20 Dec 2020 00:32:57 GMT):
the postgres of explorer has only been tested on ubuntu and MacOS, so other distros are not necessarily supposed to work, correct?

nekia (Mon, 21 Dec 2020 01:43:12 GMT):
Correct. If using explorer-db container

nekia (Mon, 21 Dec 2020 01:43:12 GMT):
Correct. If you use [explorer-db container](https://hub.docker.com/r/hyperledger/explorer-db) instead, it will work regardless your distros.

nekia (Mon, 21 Dec 2020 01:48:20 GMT):
Sorry for confusion. Currently Explorer is not using the status internally. It's should be obsoleted from `peersStatus` API.

nekia (Mon, 21 Dec 2020 01:48:20 GMT):
Sorry for confusion. Currently Explorer is not using the status internally. It should be obsoleted from `peersStatus` API.

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 07:07:47 GMT):
Please refer the case that Explorer is running as a container. In this case, in your connection profile, you need to specify a peer with URL which is directly reachable from Explorer container.

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 07:08:03 GMT):
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/examples/net1/connection-profile/first-network.json

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 07:09:23 GMT):
https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/master/README-CONFIG.md#run-hyperledger-explorer-using-docker-compose

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 07:22:22 GMT):
Explorer requires admin privilege to query chaincode info to fabric network.

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 09:40:11 GMT):
And Fabric network uses `Node OU` to confer a role onto an identity.

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 09:40:56 GMT):
This convention allows you to distinguish MSP roles by the OU present in the CommonName attribute of the X509 certificate.

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 09:43:15 GMT):
This error is saying that node ou for `admin` is undefined. Please make sure that Node OU is enabled in your each `config.yaml` ex. `crypto-artifacts/**/msp/config.yaml`

nekia (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 09:43:25 GMT):
https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-2.2/membership/membership.html#node-ou-roles-and-msps

sigma67 (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 15:18:33 GMT):
Ok, thanks for the reply :)

sigma67 (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 15:41:16 GMT):
Is it just me or are CONFIG transactions always missing the txhash? It seems it is not being returned by the Fabric Node SDK

sigma67 (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 15:41:16 GMT):
Is it just me or are CONFIG transactions always missing the txhash? It seems it is not being returned by the Fabric Node SDK. It seems other important data is missing as well, such as previous/current config. The colums read_set, write_set, chaincode_proposal_input, tx_response are all empty

sigma67 (Thu, 07 Jan 2021 15:41:16 GMT):
Is it just me or are CONFIG transactions always missing the txhash? It seems it is not being returned by the Fabric Node SDK. It seems other important data is missing as well, such as previous/current config. The colums read_set, write_set, chaincode_proposal_input, tx_response are all empty Edit: I created an issue on JIRA

greg2git (Tue, 12 Jan 2021 17:34:01 GMT):
for the sample network is it 'first-network' or 'test-network'? some github documentation seems to not have been updated since the days of byfn.

sam94 (Fri, 15 Jan 2021 16:36:00 GMT):
Hi everyone, I want to avoid any Single Point of Failure by providing multiple peers to my explorer. I have specified multiple peers in my connection-profile.json and the explorer is working but if the first peer in the connection-profile list is unreachable, the explorer does not get the required infos from other peers. Is it a normal behaviour ? If not how can I fix my issue please. (only network topology informations are not present, block and transactions infos are still present)

sam94 (Fri, 15 Jan 2021 16:36:00 GMT):
Hi everyone, I want to avoid any Single Point of Failure by providing multiple peers to my explorer. I have specified multiple peers in my connection-profile.json and the explorer is working but if the first peer in the connection-profile list is unreachable during deployment, the explorer does not get the required infos from other peers. Is it a normal behaviour ? If not how can I fix my issue please. (only network topology informations are not present, block and transactions infos are still present so I tried to declare each peer as an anchor peer to be able to execute serviceDiscovery but it did not solve my issue)

bh4rtp (Sat, 16 Jan 2021 08:12:52 GMT):
my test also fails for the single point of failure.

sam94 (Sat, 16 Jan 2021 10:35:57 GMT):
ok thanks, is it related to the last tag version or it was always the case ?

bh4rtp (Sat, 16 Jan 2021 11:52:12 GMT):
I remember 1.4 sdk can specify endorsing peers

bh4rtp (Sat, 16 Jan 2021 11:52:12 GMT):
I remember 1.4 sdk can specify endorsing peers. 2.2 uses discovery to find endorsing peer according to endorsing policies automatically. It may be a bug which has been already reported on JIRA.

bh4rtp (Sat, 16 Jan 2021 11:55:37 GMT):
https://jira.hyperledger.org/browse/FABN-1687

sigma67 (Thu, 18 Feb 2021 10:52:38 GMT):
The development build is a bit tricky to get working at the start, since it uses port 3000 instead of 8080, which HL Explorer is configured to use by default

sigma67 (Thu, 18 Feb 2021 10:52:59 GMT):
I recommend doing a npm build first to try it out and run as described in instructions

sigma67 (Thu, 18 Feb 2021 10:53:31 GMT):
If you really want to run the development build you can check our fork at https://github.com/sigma67/hypersec, we got it working

sigma67 (Thu, 18 Feb 2021 10:55:44 GMT):
Pretty much you need to tell the frontend to use server port 3000 instead of 8080 and it should work fine

Marioauguto (Fri, 19 Feb 2021 19:13:01 GMT):
Thank you friend! Do you have a script to make this compilation? correcting port 3000 to port 8000?

Marioauguto (Fri, 19 Feb 2021 19:13:44 GMT):
Thank you so much! Do you have a script to make this compilation? correcting port 3000 to port 8000?

Marioauguto (Fri, 19 Feb 2021 20:21:31 GMT):
what is the package.json folder? Is the folder inside the explorer folder? Additional configuration: you must set the proxy parameter in package.json to point to the Hyperledger Explorer backend. localhost: 8080 works well if the client is running on the same host.

Marioauguto (Fri, 19 Feb 2021 20:22:01 GMT):
I didn't find packge.jon

sigma67 (Mon, 22 Feb 2021 14:17:14 GMT):
package.json is a file in the client folder

Marioauguto (Sun, 28 Feb 2021 13:22:22 GMT):

akoita (Wed, 17 Mar 2021 13:37:09 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

akoita (Wed, 17 Mar 2021 13:44:36 GMT):
Hi, I see that the Explorer documentation mentions some authentication possibilities: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/main/README-CONFIG.md But currently we are interested in the possibility of managing authentication with Keycloak. Have anyone tried or succeeded in this operation?

nekia (Fri, 19 Mar 2021 05:10:18 GMT):
As far as I know, we've not tried it yet. Explorer is using passport.js middleware to authenticate users accessing to the dashboard. So if you use the following middleware on the top of it, you might be able to do that kind of implementation. https://github.com/louie007/passport-keycloak-oauth2-oidc

akoita (Mon, 22 Mar 2021 10:02:54 GMT):
OK, thanks, we will try this

jbkal (Fri, 09 Apr 2021 23:26:43 GMT):
Did some digging, the offending line is here: https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/main/app/platform/fabric/sync/SyncService.ts#L605 on the transaction that's causing the crash, `txObj.payload.data.last_update` is an empty object.

nekia (Sat, 10 Apr 2021 12:46:45 GMT):
I'm working on it. I could reproduce this issue with fabric v2.3. Currently explorer doesn't support v2.3. I'll have a look at adding the support.

nekia (Mon, 12 Apr 2021 06:54:11 GMT):

kh_touati (Mon, 31 May 2021 10:48:20 GMT):

munapower (Tue, 01 Jun 2021 14:57:14 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

munapower (Tue, 01 Jun 2021 14:57:16 GMT):
Hello! I am collaborating on the Fabric-Private-Chaincode stream and we would like to use Blockchain Explorer to easily show how transactions are stored using FPC. We would like to be able to also show the chaincode function and arguments that are sent (they should be encrypted). I am not sure where I would have to modify to add these fields. Any pointers are appreciated!

sigma67 (Wed, 02 Jun 2021 19:01:30 GMT):
Hyperledger Explorer uses the channel subscriptions provided by fabric-node-sdk. Your data should be somewhere in the transaction data provided by the channel subscription. I'd start by checking if the rw-sets of your transactions are being synced to HL Explorer's database

munapower (Thu, 03 Jun 2021 18:15:43 GMT):
thank you for replying. I did find that in the sync service blockchain-explorer/app/platform/fabric/sync/SyncService.ts they are obtaining the info I would like to display `chaincode_proposal_input = txObj.payload.data.actions[0].payload.chaincode_proposal_payload.input .chaincode_spec.input.args;` what I don´t know is where that field should be displayed ...

nekia (Fri, 04 Jun 2021 14:06:30 GMT):
I think you need to modify `client/src/components/View/TransactionView.js` and `app/persistence/fabric/CRUDService.ts`. In `CRUDService.ts`, `chaincode_proposal_input` field is currently filtered from API response.

nekia (Fri, 04 Jun 2021 14:07:19 GMT):
[blockchain-explorer/CRUDService.ts at main · hyperledger/blockchain-explorer](https://github.com/hyperledger/blockchain-explorer/blob/main/app/persistence/fabric/CRUDService.ts#L49)

munapower (Fri, 04 Jun 2021 14:08:10 GMT):
aaaahhhhh ok, and I wouldn't be able to do that inside the docker environment correct? I would have to clone the repository, modify and then build everything, right?

nekia (Fri, 04 Jun 2021 16:13:11 GMT):
That's right.

jeevasang (Mon, 07 Jun 2021 08:41:44 GMT):
Explorer v1.1.6 has been released!

raduke (Wed, 09 Jun 2021 18:42:03 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

cthtuf (Fri, 11 Jun 2021 06:46:52 GMT):
Has joined the channel.

cthtuf (Fri, 11 Jun 2021 06:46:53 GMT):
Hi everyone. I noticed when I add *peer* from another organization in my network and join it to channel, it *doesn't have* installed *_lifecycle* chaincode (1*) and that's the reason why *explorer*, deployed for this organization is *failed*. I found a workaround for it - to approve some chaincode, it could be even not being packed and installed, like `peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name randomchaincodename --package-id 1 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles {path_here} --cafile {path_here} --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1`. I executed it from initial peer of first organization. Somehow it forced new peer to install _livecycle chaincode (2*) and than explorer could start. ``` 1*. Right after join new peer to channel on discovery request [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": null # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< } ] Also explorer shows next lines in logs: [ERROR] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Synchronizer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> [ERROR] Sync - { FabricError: Query failed. Errors: ["Error: Peer nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com is not running chaincode _lifecycle"] at SingleQueryHandler.evaluate (/opt/explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/impl/query/singlequeryhandler.js:47:23) at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) name: 'FabricError' } [INFO] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Closing client processor >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ``` ``` 2*. Than execute peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name lifecycle --package-id 1 -o orderer_address:7050 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles path_to_cert --cafile path_to_cert --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1 and now discovery returns [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here }", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< not it's here ] } ] And explorer runs successfully. ``` For sure that way is not production ready. How to fix it and make explorer works right after deploying? I use hlf-peer 2.2.0 and hlf-explorer 1.1.4

cthtuf (Fri, 11 Jun 2021 06:46:53 GMT):
Hi everyone. I noticed when I add *peer* from another organization in my network and join it to channel, it *doesn't have* installed *_lifecycle* chaincode (1) and that's the reason why *explorer*, deployed for this organization is *failed*. I found a workaround for it - to approve some chaincode, it could be even not being packed and installed, like `peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name randomchaincodename --package-id 1 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles {path_here} --cafile {path_here} --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1`. I executed it from initial peer of first organization. Somehow it forced new peer to install _livecycle chaincode (2) and than explorer could start. ``` 1*. Right after join new peer to channel on discovery request [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": null # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< } ] Also explorer shows next lines in logs: [ERROR] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Synchronizer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> [ERROR] Sync - { FabricError: Query failed. Errors: ["Error: Peer nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com is not running chaincode _lifecycle"] at SingleQueryHandler.evaluate (/opt/explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/impl/query/singlequeryhandler.js:47:23) at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) name: 'FabricError' } [INFO] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Closing client processor >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ``` ``` 2*. Than execute peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name lifecycle --package-id 1 -o orderer_address:7050 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles path_to_cert --cafile path_to_cert --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1 and now discovery returns [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here }", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< not it's here ] } ] And explorer runs successfully. ``` For sure that way is not production ready. How to fix it and make explorer works right after deploying? I use hlf-peer 2.2.0 and hlf-explorer 1.1.4

cthtuf (Fri, 11 Jun 2021 06:46:53 GMT):
Hi everyone. I noticed when I add *peer* from another organization in my network and join it to channel, it *doesn't have* installed *_lifecycle* chaincode (1) and that's the reason why *explorer*, deployed for this organization is *failed*. I found a workaround for it - to approve some chaincode, it could be even not being packed and installed, like `peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name randomchaincodename --package-id 1 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles {path_here} --cafile {path_here} --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1`. I executed it from initial peer of first organization. Somehow it forced new peer to install _livecycle chaincode (2) and than explorer could start. ``` 1*. Right after join new peer to channel on discovery request [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 4, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{certificate here}", "Chaincodes": null # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< } ] Also explorer shows next lines in logs: [ERROR] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Synchronizer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> [ERROR] Sync - { FabricError: Query failed. Errors: ["Error: Peer nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com is not running chaincode _lifecycle"] at SingleQueryHandler.evaluate (/opt/explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/impl/query/singlequeryhandler.js:47:23) at process._tickCallback (internal/process/next_tick.js:68:7) name: 'FabricError' } [INFO] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Closing client processor >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> ``` ``` 2*. Than execute peer lifecycle chaincode approveformyorg --name lifecycle --package-id 1 -o orderer_address:7050 --tls --tlsRootCertFiles path_to_cert --cafile path_to_cert --version 1 --channelID defaultchannel --sequence 1 and now discovery returns [ { "MSPID": "RG-288-853-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-898-226-493.rg-288-853.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here}", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" ] }, { "MSPID": "RG-853-084-MSP", "LedgerHeight": 5, "Endpoint": "nd-209-598-807.rg-853-084.int.chainstack.com:7051", "Identity": "{ certificate here }", "Chaincodes": [ "_lifecycle" # <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< now it's here ] } ] And explorer runs successfully. ``` For sure that way is not production ready. How to fix it and make explorer works right after deploying? I use hlf-peer 2.2.0 and hlf-explorer 1.1.4

nekia (Thu, 17 Jun 2021 15:10:30 GMT):
If you add liveness probe with `httpGet` to `localhost:8080/auth/networklist`, you are probably able to detect unhealthy of explorer node.

nekia (Thu, 17 Jun 2021 15:41:31 GMT):
I think it will just indicate if explorer (backend) is healthy or not.

ThomasRalee (Thu, 24 Jun 2021 14:17:56 GMT):
Hey @nekia, I found 2 issues when spinning up a new explorer on a network with multiple blocks that I would like to share. 1. Explorer is making multiple `sendDiscoveryRequest` calls, 1 per block. Which retrieves the same information. What are your thoughts on calling it only once during the initialization phase instead of calling it on every block? After the DB is synced, call it once every block like how it's done currently. 2. fabricGateway.queryChainInfo error crashes the explorer. What do you think of adding a try-catch re-query flow here? ``` [2021-06-18T18:14:26.585] [ERROR] FabricGateway - Failed to get chain info from channel defaultchannel : FabricError: Query failed. Errors: ["Error: REQUEST TIMEOUT"] at SingleQueryHandler.evaluate (/Users/leeruianthomas/Public/projects/blockchain-explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/impl/query/singlequeryhandler.js:47:23) at runMicrotasks () at processTicksAndRejections (internal/process/task_queues.js:97:5) at async Transaction.evaluate (/Users/leeruianthomas/Public/projects/blockchain-explorer/node_modules/fabric-network/lib/transaction.js:276:25) [2021-06-18T18:14:26.590] [ERROR] Sync - <<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<<< Synchronizer Error >>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>>> [2021-06-18T18:14:26.590] [ERROR] Sync - TypeError: Cannot read property 'height' of null at SyncServices. nekia (Fri, 25 Jun 2021 09:10:35 GMT):

nekia (Fri, 25 Jun 2021 09:13:31 GMT):
Yes, I think, we can remove it.

nekia (Fri, 02 Jul 2021 13:03:17 GMT):
Thank you for sharing. It seems to be caused by insufficient privilege of identity you specified in connection profile. There are 2 options. Recently we changed it the code around this implementation. So if you use the latest codebase and build your own image on your local, it'll be resolved. The other one is to wait for the next release which is scheduled this weekend.

nekia (Fri, 02 Jul 2021 13:05:06 GMT):
`./build_docker_image.sh` will generate new images (explorer / explorer-db)

Is it possible to use AWS RDS PostgresDB to persist the data. Is it the best practice for explorerDB? 3. When we redeploy explorer, will it start fetching details from genesis block or it will get the last block from explorerDb and start from there?

jimkom (Tue, 20 Jul 2021 13:14:01 GMT):

jimkom (Tue, 20 Jul 2021 13:14:25 GMT):

munapower (Fri, 23 Jul 2021 20:46:22 GMT):
I Think your problem is in the docker-compose.yaml file, specifically in this section```volumes: - /"REAL PATH TO THE FILE"/blockchain-explorer/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/blockchain-explorer/connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/fabric-samples/test-network/organizations:/tmp/crypto - walletstore:/opt/explorer/wallet`````` In my case I replaced REAL PATH with ```/Users/xxx/go/src/github.com/hyperledger-labs/fabric-private-chaincode/samples/deployment/test-network``` ```

munapower (Fri, 23 Jul 2021 20:46:22 GMT):
I Think your problem is in the docker-compose.yaml file, specifically in this section```volumes: - /"REAL PATH TO THE FILE"/blockchain-explorer/config.json:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/config.json - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/blockchain-explorer/connection-profile:/opt/explorer/app/platform/fabric/connection-profile - /"REAL PATH TO THE DIRECTORY"/fabric-samples/test-network/organizations:/tmp/crypto - walletstore:/opt/explorer/wallet`````` In my case I replaced REAL PATH with ```/Users/xxx/go/src/github.com/hyperledger-labs/fabric-private-chaincode/samples/deployment/test-network```

@kosarlatif

Gavimat (Sat, 02 Oct 2021 15:48:15 GMT):
Could anyone help me?

nekia (Sun, 03 Oct 2021 07:34:33 GMT):
In your `connection-profile.json`, you have configured incorrect path for adminPrivateKey. You need to specify valid path on the `explorer` container which start with `/tmp/crypto/...`, not on host machine which start with `/home/gavimat/...`.

nekia (Sun, 03 Oct 2021 07:34:33 GMT):
In your `connection-profile.json`, you have configured incorrect path for adminPrivateKey, signedCert and tlsCACerts. You need to specify valid path on the `explorer` container which start with `/tmp/crypto/...`, not on host machine which start with `/home/gavimat/...`.

Gavimat (Mon, 04 Oct 2021 19:28:58 GMT):

Does anyone have some contents/guides that explain how to configure Hyperledger Explorer?

nekia (Tue, 05 Oct 2021 12:29:30 GMT):
Can you try again with the following instead of your connection profile? And you can find example under `examples/net1` directory and learn about connection profile more in [here](https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-1.4/tutorial-network-config.html) and here. ``` { "name": "test-network", "version": "1.0.0", "client": { "tlsEnable": true, "adminCredential": { "id": "exploreradmin", "password": "exploreradminpw" }, "enableAuthentication": true, "organization": "Org1MSP", "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "300" }, "orderer": "300" } } }, "channels": { "mychannel": { "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": {} } } }, "organizations": { "Org1MSP": { "mspid": "Org1MSP", "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/keystore/priv_sk" }, "peers": ["peer0.org1.example.com"], "signedCert": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/signcerts/Admin1@org1.example.com-cert.pem" } } }, "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpcs://peer0.org1.example.com:7051", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com" } } } } ```

nekia (Tue, 05 Oct 2021 12:29:30 GMT):
Can you try again with the following instead of your connection profile? And you can find example under `examples/net1` directory and learn about connection profile more in [here](https://hyperledger.github.io/fabric-sdk-node/release-1.4/tutorial-network-config.html) and [here](https://hyperledger-fabric.readthedocs.io/en/release-2.2/developapps/connectionprofile.html). ``` { "name": "test-network", "version": "1.0.0", "client": { "tlsEnable": true, "adminCredential": { "id": "exploreradmin", "password": "exploreradminpw" }, "enableAuthentication": true, "organization": "Org1MSP", "connection": { "timeout": { "peer": { "endorser": "300" }, "orderer": "300" } } }, "channels": { "mychannel": { "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": {} } } }, "organizations": { "Org1MSP": { "mspid": "Org1MSP", "adminPrivateKey": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/keystore/priv_sk" }, "peers": ["peer0.org1.example.com"], "signedCert": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/users/Admin@org1.example.com/msp/signcerts/Admin1@org1.example.com-cert.pem" } } }, "peers": { "peer0.org1.example.com": { "tlsCACerts": { "path": "/tmp/crypto/peerOrganizations/org1.example.com/peers/peer0.org1.example.com/tls/ca.crt" }, "url": "grpcs://peer0.org1.example.com:7051", "grpcOptions": { "ssl-target-name-override": "peer0.org1.example.com" } } } } ```

Gavimat (Tue, 05 Oct 2021 20:39:19 GMT):
I manage to find what I was doing wrong by starting all over again and again, following the steps mentioned on Hyperledger Explorer GitHub repository... and it was a silly mistake: the name of the network I was working with wasn't as I thought. By running "docker network ls" command I realized that I had named it as "artifacts_test".

maciejjedrzejczyk (Wed, 06 Oct 2021 12:14:53 GMT):

maciejjedrzejczyk (Wed, 06 Oct 2021 12:14:54 GMT):
Hi, I am planning to deploy a HLF environment on Raspberry Pi and I was curious if anyone tried to create a Hyperledger Explorer docker image compatible with ARM64 devices. Any links to existing images or instructions on how to do that would be greatly appreciated, thanks!

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:25:31 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it: * Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it: - Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu - `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it: * Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu ** `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it: * Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu * `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register` * [multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub](multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub) * Edit baseimage in Dockerfile and postgres_Dockerfile to arm64 image (e.g. arm64v8/node) * rebuild images by running `./build_image.sh`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it * Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu * `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register` * [multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub](multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub) * Edit baseimage in Dockerfile and postgres_Dockerfile to arm64 image (e.g. arm64v8/node) * rebuild images by running `./build_image.sh`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
* Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu * `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register` * [multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub](multiarch/qemu-user-static - Docker Image | Docker Hub) * Edit baseimage in Dockerfile and postgres_Dockerfile to arm64 image (e.g. arm64v8/node) * rebuild images by running `./build_image.sh`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
* Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu * `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register` * https://hub.docker.com/r/multiarch/qemu-user-static/ * Edit baseimage in Dockerfile and postgres_Dockerfile to arm64 image (e.g. arm64v8/node) * rebuild images by running `./build_image.sh`

nekia (Wed, 13 Oct 2021 14:26:54 GMT):
I've not tried it for HL Explorer, but I think the following steps will make it: * Setup ARM64 image build environment by using qemu * `docker run --rm --privileged multiarch/qemu-user-static:register` * https://hub.docker.com/r/multiarch/qemu-user-static/ * Edit baseimage in Dockerfile and postgres_Dockerfile to arm64 image (e.g. arm64v8/node) * rebuild images by running `./build_image.sh`

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:56:29 GMT):
Hi channel, I keep getting this error while deploying explorer in kubernetes: ```[2022-02-03T13:53:10.588] [ERROR] FabricGateway - Failed to create wallet, please check the configuration, and valid file paths: {} [2022-02-03T13:53:10.589] [ERROR] FabricClient - ExplorerError { name: 'ExplorerError', message: '[\n' + " 'Failed to create wallet, please check the configuration, and valid file paths'\n" + ']' }```

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:56:29 GMT):
Hi channel, I keep getting this error while deploying explorer in kubernetes: ```{ code: 0, message: "Registration of 'vulosadmin6' failed: Identity 'vulosadmin6' is already registered" } ],```

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:56:29 GMT):
Hi channel, I keep getting this error while deploying explorer in kubernetes: ```{ code: 0, message: "Registration of 'vulosadmin6' failed: Identity 'admin1' is already registered" } ],```

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:57:41 GMT):
The message is very descriptive and I understand that `admin1` is already registered

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:58:30 GMT):
However this issue arrises because when I see the logs at `fabric-ca-server` the fabric-ca is being called multiple times to register `admin1`

gentios (Thu, 03 Feb 2022 13:58:59 GMT):
At the 1st time its everything ok with a `200` but than `explorer` keeps calling it and that's why its failing

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Thu, 10 Mar 2022 23:21:52 GMT):
Dear all, Is anybody facing memory maxed out issue because of hyperledger explorer db ? In my case, I am running the hyperledger explorer and hyperledger db as docker swarm services.

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Thu, 10 Mar 2022 23:21:52 GMT):
Dear all, Is anybody facing memory maxed out / CPU usage issue(198.74%) because of hyperledger explorer db ? In my case, I am running the hyperledger explorer and hyperledger db as docker swarm services. The output of docker stats command is below : We can see hyperledger_explorer db service is consuming very high memory and CPU % . Because of this docker memory maxed out issue occurs and docker restarts. This affects other services in the swarm . Can anybody help me to find out the reason behind this. CONTAINER ID NAME CPU % MEM USAGE / LIMIT MEM % NET I/O BLOCK I/O PIDS bd4468047c88 portainer.1.hahofoec71nxgwn0pa0b41fuy 0.00% 6.75MiB / 3.852GiB 0.17% 42.9kB / 4.37MB 4.29MB / 1.47MB 9 90bdc2ab2442 hlf_explorer_db.1.np9y1q7q3mmy3n7cftyy9kzku 198.74% 2.348GiB / 3.852GiB 60.96% 119MB / 40MB 56.1MB / 1.74GB 21 2d20f730280c swarm_visualizer.1.xke7j0776qhxvldhijpx15kyd 0.00% 60.62MiB / 3.852GiB 1.54% 1.97MB / 5.07MB 81.6MB / 0B 12 df6be87796bf hlf_explorer.1.vm4laakfhnt80l45akt3rh0pt 0.00% 75.02MiB / 3.852GiB 1.90% 1.68GB / 1.58GB 7.94GB / 0B 12 32b778fa56a4 portainer_agent.upmnze7aagx50k9od7vu6rvd9.z2dgascbme56zofo8s71ewscz 0.09% 8.41MiB / 3.852GiB 0.21% 483kB / 128kB 2.92GB / 0B 9 105695548e57 rest-api-service.1.szkq2wxp3qv6j23vfmf7jicm0 0.00% 55.34MiB / 3.852GiB 1.40% 2.39MB / 2.88MB 145MB / 0B 12

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Thu, 10 Mar 2022 23:21:52 GMT):
Dear all, Is anybody facing memory maxed out / CPU usage issue(198.74%) because of hyperledger explorer db ? In my case, I am running the hyperledger explorer and hyperledger db as docker swarm services. The output of docker stats command is below : We can see hyperledger_explorer db service is consuming very high memory and CPU % . Because of this docker memory maxed out issue occurs and docker restarts. This affects other services in the swarm . Can anybody help me to find out the reason behind this. `CONTAINER ID NAME CPU % MEM USAGE / LIMIT MEM % NET I/O BLOCK I/O PIDS bd4468047c88 portainer.1.hahofoec71nxgwn0pa0b41fuy 0.00% 6.75MiB / 3.852GiB 0.17% 42.9kB / 4.37MB 4.29MB / 1.47MB 9 90bdc2ab2442 hlf_explorer_db.1.np9y1q7q3mmy3n7cftyy9kzku 198.74% 2.348GiB / 3.852GiB 60.96% 119MB / 40MB 56.1MB / 1.74GB 21 2d20f730280c swarm_visualizer.1.xke7j0776qhxvldhijpx15kyd 0.00% 60.62MiB / 3.852GiB 1.54% 1.97MB / 5.07MB 81.6MB / 0B 12 df6be87796bf hlf_explorer.1.vm4laakfhnt80l45akt3rh0pt 0.00% 75.02MiB / 3.852GiB 1.90% 1.68GB / 1.58GB 7.94GB / 0B 12 32b778fa56a4 portainer_agent.upmnze7aagx50k9od7vu6rvd9.z2dgascbme56zofo8s71ewscz 0.09% 8.41MiB / 3.852GiB 0.21% 483kB / 128kB 2.92GB / 0B 9 105695548e57 rest-api-service.1.szkq2wxp3qv6j23vfmf7jicm0 0.00% 55.34MiB / 3.852GiB 1.40% 2.39MB / 2.88MB 145MB / 0B 12`

AnandhakumarPalanisamy (Thu, 10 Mar 2022 23:21:52 GMT):
Dear all, Is anybody facing memory maxed out / CPU usage issue(198.74%) because of hyperledger explorer db ? In my case, I am running the hyperledger explorer and hyperledger db as docker swarm services. The output of docker stats command is below : We can see the hyperledger_explorer db service is consuming very high memory( 2.348GiB / 3.852GiB ) and CPU(198.74%) . Because of this docker memory maxed out issue occurs and docker restarts. This affects other services in the swarm . Can anybody help me to find out the reason behind this. *CONTAINER ID NAME CPU % MEM USAGE / LIMIT MEM % NET I/O BLOCK I/O PIDS* bd4468047c88 portainer.1.hahofoec71nxgwn0pa0b41fuy 0.00% 6.75MiB / 3.852GiB 0.17% 42.9kB / 4.37MB 4.29MB / 1.47MB 9 90bdc2ab2442 hlf_explorer_db.1.np9y1q7q3mmy3n7cftyy9kzku 198.74% 2.348GiB / 3.852GiB 60.96% 119MB / 40MB 56.1MB / 1.74GB 21 2d20f730280c swarm_visualizer.1.xke7j0776qhxvldhijpx15kyd 0.00% 60.62MiB / 3.852GiB 1.54% 1.97MB / 5.07MB 81.6MB / 0B 12 df6be87796bf hlf_explorer.1.vm4laakfhnt80l45akt3rh0pt 0.00% 75.02MiB / 3.852GiB 1.90% 1.68GB / 1.58GB 7.94GB / 0B 12 32b778fa56a4 portainer_agent.upmnze7aagx50k9od7vu6rvd9.z2dgascbme56zofo8s71ewscz 0.09% 8.41MiB / 3.852GiB 0.21% 483kB / 128kB 2.92GB / 0B 9 105695548e57 rest-api-service.1.szkq2wxp3qv6j23vfmf7jicm0 0.00% 55.34MiB / 3.852GiB 1.40% 2.39MB / 2.88MB 145MB / 0B 12

nekia (Sat, 12 Mar 2022 04:47:23 GMT):
Hyperledger chat is migrating from Rocket.Chat to Discord. There is a explore channel in Discord that can be used in place of this one: https://discord.com/channels/905194001349627914/941483844308185138 To sign up for the Hyperledger Discord server, use this link: https://discord.gg/hyperledger
